name: Baguansanxue (T 11.30*)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.30* Baguansanxue , is on the dorsal aspect of the middle finger, along the radial margin of the proximal phalangeal bone, 0.25 cun proximal to the midpoint of the proximal phalanx (line H).
primary_indications: Primary: Hemiplegia, inability to raise arms, wei zheng (atrophy syndrome) Arm pain, leg pain, frozen shoulder
secondary_indications: Secondary: Tinnitus
techniques: Needle obliquely towards the fingertips 0.2 - 0.5 cun for arm and leg pain. For hemiplegia, needle obliquely towards the fingertips 0.1 - 0.2 cun .

name: Baguansixue (T 11.31*)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.31* Baguansixue , is located on the dorsal aspect of the middle finger, along the ulnar margin of the proximal phalangeal bone, 0.25 cun proximal to the midpoint of the proximal phalanx (line F).
primary_indications: Primary: Hemiplegia, inability to raise arms, wei zheng (atrophy syndrome) Arm pain, leg pain, frozen shoulder
secondary_indications: Secondary: Tinnitus
techniques: Needle obliquely towards the fingertips 0.2 - 0.5 cun for arm and leg pain. For hemiplegia, needle obliquely towards the fingertips 0.1 - 0.2 cun .

name: Beimian (T 44.07)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.07 Beimian , is overlaps with Jianyu (LI 15) , which is in the center of the depression anterior and inferior to the acromion when the arm is raised. Some sources state Beimian (T 44.07) is 1 cun posterior to Jianyu (LI 15) .
primary_indications: Primary: Abdominal bloating, distension and fullness, gas Fatigue, weak voice, low voice
secondary_indications: Secondary: Vomiting, acute enteritis, cholera Difficulty with pronunciation, laryngitis, sore throat Scrofula Weakness of the legs Frozen shoulder, supraspinatus tendonitis
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun perpendicularly. Fatigue, weakness of the legs, vomiting, acute enteritis, and cholera, bleed this point and 4 points (above, below, left, and right) around the point (5 points total). Supraspinatus tendinitis, needle 2 - 3 cun towards Jiquan (HT 1) . Frozen shoulder, needle 2 - 3 cun towards the deltoid muscle.

name: Biyi (T 1010.22)
location: This point is in the depression on the alae of the nose, midway between the lateral border of the alae and the tip of the nose.
primary_indications: Primary: Pain due to qi deficiency and/or stagnation
secondary_indications: Secondary: Supraorbital pain Vertigo, migraine, dizziness, blurry vision Hemiplegia, fatigue, tongue pain, tongue stiffness or tightness with difficulty speaking, facial paralysis, sore throat Pain in the limbs, fibromyalgia, sciatica, nerve pain due to Kidney deficiency, arthritis
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun .

name: Boqiu (T 77.04)
location: This point is 1.5 cun distal to Chengshan (BL 57) on the midline of the posterior aspect of the lower leg where the Achilles tendon leaves the gastrocnemius muscle.
primary_indications: Primary: Cramps and spasms of the lower leg Upper back pain (T4 area)
secondary_indications: Secondary: Nosebleed Occipital headache Lower back pain Huo luan (sudden turmoil disorder) Hemorrhoids Athlete's foot, tetanus, polio with clubfoot
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun . It is best if the tip of the needle touches the bone. For severe cramping of the calf, needle may need to be retained for 2-3 hours. This point can also be bled. Bleeding visible dark veins near this point can immediately relieve back pain and spasms.

name: Cesanli (T 77.22)
location: This point is 1.5 cun lateral to Zusanli (ST 36) , between the ST and the GB channels.
primary_indications: Primary: Toothache, facial paralysis, headache, migraine, sinusitis Intercostal neuralgia Abdominal pain due to appendicitis
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side. This point can also be bled, especially for disorders of the upper jiao .

name: Cexiasanli (T 77.23)
location: This point is 1.5 cun lateral and 2 cun distal to Zusanli (ST 36) , between the ST and the GB channels.
primary_indications: Primary: Toothache, facial paralysis, headache, migraine, sinusitis Intercostal neuralgia Abdominal pain due to appendicitis
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side. This point can also be bled.

name: Changmen (T 33.10)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.10 Changmen , is on the SI channel, 3 cun proximal to the dorsal crease of the wrist.
primary_indications: Primary: All digestive and intestinal disorders Stomach ulcer, duodenal ulcer, peritonitis, acute or chronic enteritis, diarrhea, tenesmus, gastroenteritis, colitis, enteritis due to hepatitis, disorders of the anus and/or rectum, abdominal pain, epigastric pain, dysentery, vomiting, cholecystitis, urgency of defecation
secondary_indications: Secondary: Blurry vision, lightheadedness
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 1 cun .

name: Chongxian (T 22.02)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.02 Chongxian , is on the thenar eminence, between the first and second metacarpal bones, 1 cun below Chongzi (T 22.01) , 2 cun from the skin fold. It is exactly on the opposite side of Linggu (T 22.05) , which is on the dorsal aspect of the hand.
primary_indications: Primary: Upper back, neck, scapular, and interscapular pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Knee pain (especially the medial side on the SP channel) Common cold, flu, fever, cough, asthma, pneumonia, difficulty expectorating sputum Palpitations, tachycardia, hypertension Finger stiffness
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 1 cun . Deep needling tends to produce better results. Needle contralateral to the affected side when treating pain. When treating everything else, needle the side of Chongxian (T 22.02) where there is more pain upon palpation. This point can also be bled. Blue veins in this area indicate poor digestion or pain of the neck/shoulder/scapular area as this general area is reflective of the Stomach and the neck/shoulder/scapular areas.

name: Chongxiao (T DT.17)
location: 3 points total on the spine Point 1 is at the level of S3 of the sacral vertebra. Point 2 is 1 cun inferior from Point 1. Point 3 is 1 cun inferior from Point 2.
primary_indications: Primary: Cerebellar pain, cerebellar distension, occipital headache, nape pain
techniques: This point can be bled.

name: Chongzi (T 22.01)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.01 Chongzi , is on the thenar eminence, about 1 cun below the first and second metacarpal skin fold.
primary_indications: Primary: Upper back pain (especially between scapula and neck), neck pain Respiratory disorders: asthma (especially in children), pneumonia, common cold, cough, fever, sore throat, emphysema, lung cancer, laryngitis, pharyngitis, lung cancer
secondary_indications: Secondary: Tachycardia, hypertension, chest pain Finger stiffness
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 1 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side when treating pain. When treating everything else, needle the side of Chongzi (T 22.01) where there is more pain upon palpation. This point can also be bled, especially in pediatric cases.

name: Dabai (T 22.04)
location: There are discrepancies among different sources as to the exact location of The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.04 Dabai . Some references state this point overlaps with Sanjian (LI 3) and some say Hegu (LI 4) . Therefore, palpate for the most tender point and needle the ah shi point on or between these two points.
primary_indications: Primary: Respiratory disorders: asthma (children), high fever (children), pneumonia, emphysema, fluids in the lungs, common cold, mei he qi (plum-pit qi), lung cancer Sciatica, upper back pain, lower back pain, chest pain Eye pain, migraine, headache
techniques: Bleed the point or nearby veins for respiratory disorders (asthma, fever, pneumonia). Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1 cun along the bone. Needle contralateral to the affected side.

name: Dajian (T 11.01)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.01 Dajian , is located on the palmar aspect of the index finger, midway along the radial margin of the proximal phalangeal bone (line B).
primary_indications: Primary: Hernia: inguinal hernia, bearing down sensation of the testicles, abdominal distension or bloating Heart disease, palpitations, shortness of breath Acute or chronic enteritis
secondary_indications: Secondary: Knee pain, finger numbness Canthus pain, TMJ pain, tonsillitis Pediatric asthma, gan ji (infantile malnutrition)
techniques: Needle perpendicularly, adjacent to the edge of the bone, towards the dorsal aspect of the hand. Needle contralateral to the affected side. For HT conditions, needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun . For SI conditions, hernia, knee pain, and other conditions, needle 0.2 - 0.3 cun . Bleeding is also effective for hernia if there are nearby veins or dark spots.

name: Dan (T 11.13)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.13 Dan , is a two-point set on the dorsal aspect of the middle finger, ulnar and radial to the midpoint of the proximal phalanx along the margins of the phalangeal bone (lines F and H).
primary_indications: Primary: Night crying in infants and children Hysteria (Gallbladder deficiency pattern)
secondary_indications: Secondary: Palpitations, shaking and fear Jaundice Soreness and swelling of the calf from overexertion Lateral ankle pain, knee pain Stye
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.2 cun towards the palm. This point can also be bled.

name: Dihuang (T 77.19)
location: This point is located on the SP channel, 7 cun proximal to the tip of the medial malleolus.
primary_indications: Primary: Kidney disorders: nephritis, edema, proteinuria Any urinary disorders: lin zheng (dysuria syndrome), xue lin (bloody dysuria), cystitis, nocturnal emission, ascites Kidney deficiency with impotence, premature ejaculation, spermatorrhea, back soreness and weakness
secondary_indications: Secondary: Dysmenorrhea, myoma, uterine fibroids, irregular menstruation Diabetes
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun .

name: Ding Zhu (T DT.10)
location: 22 points total The first set of 12 points is 3 cun lateral to the spinous process of T4 to T9 (6 points on each side). 10 of the 12 points overlap with Gaohuangshu (BL 43) , Shentang (BL 44) , Yixi (BL 45) , Geguan (BL 46) , Hunmen (BL 47) . The second set of 10 points is 6 cun lateral to the spinous process of T4 to T8 (5 points on each side). 2 of the 10 points overlap with Tianzong (SI 11) .
primary_indications: Primary: Back pain due to arteriosclerosis, sudden onset of back pain due to wrong posture with difficulty breathing

name: Dingke (T 44.28)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.28* Dingke , is 1.6 cun proximal and 0.5 cun anterior to Quchi (LI 11) , which is on the lateral end of the transverse cubital crease.
primary_indications: Primary: Cough
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Dishi (T 33.14)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.14 Dishi , is 7 cun proximal to the wrist crease on the LU or PC channel, 3 cun proximal to Renshi (T 33.13) . On the LU channel, it overlaps Kongzui (LU 6) .
primary_indications: Primary: Asthma Cardiac insufficiency, arrhythmia
secondary_indications: Secondary: All respiratory disorders: common cold, bronchitis, rhinitis, sinusitis Headache, upper body pain, arm pain, lack of flexibility of the hand Heart disease, including palpitations, chest tightness Kidney deficiency, hernia
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 1 - 1.5 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected area. Use shallow insertion for respiratory issues and deep insertion for cardiac disorders. Since this point is on or in between the PC and LU channel, select the PC channel to treat cardiovascular problems and use the LU channel to treat respiratory disorders.

name: Dizong (T 44.09)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.09 Dizong , is 1 cun distal to Binao (LI 14) and 6 cun proximal to the cubital crease, in the depression between the lateral border of the humerus and the m. biceps brachii. Some books indicate this point is on the LU channel.
primary_indications: Primary: Cardiovascular disorders: Any cardiopathy, including coronary heart disease, palpitations, arteriosclerosis, heart attack, angina, congestive heart failure Cerebral vascular occlusion, embolism, cerebral thrombosis Stiffness of the tongue, hemiplegia, facial paralysis Yang collapse
techniques: Needle 1 cun for mild conditions. Needle up to 2 cun bilaterally for severe conditions.

name: Er Bei (T 99.07)
location: This point is approximately at the midpoint of the posterior ear, 0.3 cun above Muer (T 99.02).
primary_indications: Primary: Laryngitis, throat tumor, tonsillitis, difficulty opening the mouth, sore throat, chewing dysfunction
secondary_indications: Secondary: Acne, migraine, conjunctivitis, dermatological disorders, headache, fever, high blood pressure

name: Erhuan (T 99.01)
location: This point is in the center of the ear lobe. It is at the same location as the auricular Eye Point in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
primary_indications: Primary: Hangover and associated symptoms
secondary_indications: Secondary: Eye disorders
techniques: Needle 0.1 cun towards the face.

name: Erjiaoming (T 11.12)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.12 Erjiaoming , is a two-point set on the dorsal aspect of the middle finger, evenly distributed along the midline of the proximal phalanx (line G). Divide the proximal phalanx into thirds, and locate these two points at 1/3 and 2/3 the distance between the PIP and MCP joints.
primary_indications: Primary: Low back pain (L4), acute back sprain Pain of the nasal bone (sinus pain), supraorbital pain, sinus pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Acute chest or rib pain
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.5 cun horizontally towards the little finger.

name: Ersan (T 99.08)
location: This is a three-point set on the outer edge of the helix of the ear and earlobe. The top point is at the apex. The middle point is at the outer midpoint of the helix. The bottom point is at the most inferior point of the earlobe.
primary_indications: Primary: Cholera One-sided headache, migraine Common cold, tonsillitis Stubborn facial spasms Stye
techniques: Bleed only two of the three points each time per ear. Unilateral or bilateral needling are both appropriate.

name: Eryuan (T 99.11)*
location: This point is on the outer edge of the ear where the helix meets the earlobe.
primary_indications: Primary: Hangover Motion sickness
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 cun . This point can also be bled.

name: Erzhong (T 77.06)
location: This point is between the GB and ST channels, 5 cun proximal to the lateral malleolus and 1 cun anterior to the fibula. It is 2 cun above Yizhong (T 77.05) .
primary_indications: Primary: Hyperthyroidism (caused by heart disease), bulging of the eyes, enlarged thyroid, tonsillitis, liver disease, rib pain, teeth clenching at night, migraine Breast disorders: mastitis, fibrocystic breast disease, breast tumors, breast cancer, breast pain Tumors and cancer: brain, breast, esophageal
secondary_indications: Secondary: Meningitis Post-concussion symptoms Spleen diseases, abdominal mass
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun . Needle the healthy side when treating TMJ or deviation of the eyes and mouth. This point can also be bled.

name: Fanhoujue (T 22.12)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.12 Fanhoujue , is on the dorsal aspect of the hand, 1 cun distal to Linggu (T 22.05) at the ulnar margin of the first metacarpal bone.
primary_indications: Primary: Upper back pain, shoulder pain, clavicle pain
techniques: Needle 0.5 cun along the edge of the bone.

name: Feiqier (T 44.26)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.26* Feiqier , is 3 cun above Feiqiyi (T 44.25)* , or 6 cun proximal to the tip of the elbow, between the LI and TH channels.
primary_indications: Primary: Shortness of breath, tracheitis, dry mouth, asthma, bronchitis
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Feiqiyi (T 44.25)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.25* Feiqiyi, is 3 cun proximal to the tip of the elbow, between the LI and the TH channels.
primary_indications: Primary: Shortness of breath, tracheitis, dry mouth, asthma, bronchitis
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Feiqizhong (T 99.20)*
location: This point is inferior to the highest point of the antitragus, almost horizontally leveled with the bottom of the intertragic notch. It is approximately at the same location as the auricular Forehead Point in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
primary_indications: Primary: Emphysema, water in the lungs
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.2 cun .

name: Feixin (T 11.11)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.11 Feixin , is a two-point set on the dorsal aspect of the middle finger, evenly distributed along the midline of the middle phalanx (line G). Divide the middle phalanx into thirds, and locate these two points at 1/3 and 2/3 of the distance between the PIP and DIP joints.
primary_indications: Primary: All spinal disorders: neck pain, occipital pain, spine pain (best for coccyx), back pain, leg pain, calf pain, heel pain
techniques: Needle 0.5 cun horizontally towards the little finger.

name: Fenjin (T 44.01)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.01 Fenjin , is on the LU channel, 1.5 cun proximal to Chize (LU 5) on the anterior aspect of the upper arm.
primary_indications: Primary: Common cold, cough, rhinitis, laryngitis, allergic rhinitis
secondary_indications: Secondary: Throat cancer
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1 cun .

name: Fenzhishang (T DT.01)
location: This point is on the SI channel at the inferior junction of the humerus and scapula.
primary_indications: Primary: Poisoning (drug, medication, gas, radiation, food, bites by toxic animals such as snakes, scorpions, centipedes, spiders, bees, wasp), suicide attempts by taking poison (mild cases only) Foul breath, armpit odor Generalized pruritus, rash, itching Rabies Painful urination, lin zheng (dysuria syndrome), sexually transmitted disease with urinary dysfunction
secondary_indications: Secondary: Mastitis Diabetes
techniques: Needle 1 - 1.5 cun .

name: Fenzhixia (T DT.02)
location: This point is on the SI channel, 1.5 cun inferior and 0.5 cun medial to the inferior junction of the humerus and scapula, close to Jianzhen (SI 9) .
primary_indications: Primary: Poisoning (drug, medication, gas, radiation, food, bites by toxic animals such as snakes, scorpions, centipedes, spiders, bees), suicide attempts by taking poison (mild cases only) Foul breath, armpit odor Generalized pruritus, rash, itching Rabies Painful urination, lin zheng (dysuria syndrome), sexually transmitted disease with urinary dysfunction
secondary_indications: Secondary: Mastitis Diabetes
techniques: Needle 1 - 1.5 cun .

name: Fu Chao Er Shi San (T VT.05)
location: 23 points total The first 7 points are on the CV channel. Points 1 and 2 are 1 cun and 2 cun superior to the umbilicus, overlapping Shuifen (CV 9) and Xiawan (CV 10) . Points 3-7 are all below the umbilicus, starting at 1 cun inferior. Each subsequent point is then 1 cun inferior to the previous one, totaling 5 points. They overlap with Yinjiao (CV 7) , Shimen (CV 5) , Guanyuan (CV 4) , Zhongji (CV 3) , Qugu (CV 2) . The second set of 8 points is 1 cun lateral to the CV channel (4 points on each side). Points 8 and 9 are leveled with the umbilicus. Points 10 and 11 are 1 cun superior to Points 8 and 9. Points 12 and 13 are 1 cun inferior to Points 8 and 9. Points 14 and 15 are 2 cun inferior to Points 8 and 9. The third set of 8 points is 2 cun lateral to the CV channel (4 points on each side). Points 16 and 17 are leveled with the umbilicus, overlapping Tianshu (ST 25) . Points 18 and 19 are 1 cun superior to Points 16 and 17, overlapping Huaroumen (ST 24) . Points 20 and 21 are 1 cun inferior to Points 16 and 17, overlapping Wailing (ST 26) . Points 22 and 23 are 2 cun inferior to Points 16 and 17, overlapping Daju (ST 27) .
primary_indications: Primary: Enteritis, intestinal cancer, colon cancer, navel pain, food poisoning with abdominal pain but no vomiting, appendicitis Pelvic Inflammatory Disease, uteritis Nephritis, renal pain
techniques: This point can be bled.

name: Fuchang (T 77.12)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 3 cun distal to Tiaokou (ST 38) , or 11 cun below Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament on the knee.
primary_indications: Primary: Enteritis, stomach pain, bloating, diarrhea, chang feng (intestinal wind) Teeth grinding at night Edema of the lower body Dyspnea Heat stroke
secondary_indications: Secondary: Large acne, this point is ineffective for small acne Bone spurs, especially knee and ankle spurs
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun . Needling along the tibia can treat bone spurs (knee and heel spurs). This point can also be bled. Bleeding the dark veins in this area can also be effective to treat patients with a chronic history of any of the above conditions.

name: Fuding (T 44.04)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.04 Fuding , is on the TH channel, on the posterior aspect of the upper arm, 1 cun proximal to Xiaoluo (TH 12) and 2.5 cun proximal to Shouying (T 44.03) .
primary_indications: Primary: Hypertension, dizziness, headache Fatigue, exhaustion, liver weakness
techniques: Needle 0.3 cun for fatigue and exhaustion, and 0.5 cun for everything else.

name: Fugesan (T 33.20)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.20* Fugesan , is a three-point set on the LI channel. The first point is 0.8 cun distal to Quchi (LI 11) , which is on the lateral end of the transverse cubital crease. The other two points are 0.8 cun medial and 0.8 cun lateral to the first point.
primary_indications: Primary: Very severe common cold Pain and soreness in the bones and tendons of the entire back
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Fugesan (T 44.30)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point Fugesan has been renumbered to T 33.20. It was initially numbered incorrectly in the 44.xx zone. The location of this point is on the forearm, and therefore, is in the 33.xx zone. Please see Fugesan (T 33.20)* for point information.

name: Fujian (T 11.03)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.03 Fujian , is on the palmar aspect of the index finger, along the radial margin of the middle phalangeal bone (line B). Divide the middle phalanx into thirds, and locate this point at the junction of the distal 1/3 and middle 1/3 of this distance.
primary_indications: Primary: Hernia: inguinal hernia, femoral hernia
secondary_indications: Secondary: Abdominal distension, bloating, stomachache Urinary tract infection, cystitis Toothache
techniques: Needle perpendicularly, adjacent to the edge of the bone, 0.1 - 0.2 cun towards the dorsal aspect of the hand. Bleeding is also effective for hernia if there are nearby veins or dark spots. The therapeutic effect is most apparent when yellow fluids can be squeezed out when bleeding this point.

name: Fuke (T 11.24)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.24 Fuke , is a two-point set on the on the dorsal aspect of the thumb, along the ulnar margin of the proximal phalangeal bone (line F). Divide the proximal phalanx into thirds, and locate these two points at 1/3 and 2/3 the distance between the MCP and IP joints.
primary_indications: Primary: All acute or chronic gynecological disorders Any menstrual irregularities, dysmenorrhea before, during or after menstruation, PMS, lower abdominal distension, bloating, pain, migraine, headache Leukorrhea, yeast infection, uteritis Myoma, fibroids Infertility Retroverted, anteverted uterus, or uterus tilted to the right or left Vaginal flatulence Post-partum arthritis
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.3 cun perpendicularly along the edge of the bone, towards the palm. This point can also be bled.

name: Fukuai (T 1010.15)
location: This point is 0.5 cun lateral to the inferior border of the ala nasi, close to Yingxiang (LI 20) .
primary_indications: Primary: Abdominal distension, abdominal pain, bloating Hernia
techniques: Needle in any direction 0.1 - 0.3 cun . This point can also be bled.

name: Fuyuan (T 11.22)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.22 Fuyuan , is three-point set on the palmar aspect of the ring finger, along the ulnar margin of the proximal phalangeal bone (line D). Divide the proximal phalanx into fourths, and locate these three points at 1/4, 1/2, and 3/4 the distance between the MCP and PIP joints.
primary_indications: Primary: Bone swelling, osteoarthritis
secondary_indications: Secondary: Tendonitis Sciatica, back pain Bone spurs, bone cancer
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.3 cun . This point also can be bled for clear/yellowish fluids.

name: Ganlingsanxue (T 33.18*)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.18* Ganlingsanxue , is a three-point set on the HT channel, 3 cun , 6 cun , and 9 cun proximal to the wrist crease.
primary_indications: Primary: Hepatic disorders: hepatitis, liver cirrhosis, hypochondriac pain, leukemia, liver pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Splenomegaly Hemiplegia, inflammation of the spinal cord membrane Sciatic pain, soreness of the back, pain of the tendons and bones
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1.5 cun or obliquely up to 2 cun .

name: Ganmaoer (T 88.08)
location: This point is on the SP channel, 13 cun proximal to the upper margin of the patella and 2 cun medial to the anterior midline of the thigh. It is 2.5 cun superior to Ganmaoyi (T 88.07) , 1 cun medial to Jiemeisan (T 88.06) .
primary_indications: Primary: Severe common cold or flu with or without headache, high fever and chills
secondary_indications: Secondary: Impotence, spermatorrhea
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 1 - 2 cun . Slow insertion is recommended.

name: Ganmaosan (T DT.12)
location: 3 points total Point 1 is on the spine, below the spinous process of T1. It overlaps with Taodao (GV 13) . Points 2 and 3 are 3 cun lateral to the spinous process of T3, one on each side, overlapping Pohu (BL 42) .
primary_indications: Primary: Severe common cold
techniques: Needle subcutaneously. This point can also be bled. Both are very effective.

name: Ganmaoyi (T 88.07)
location: This point is on the SP channel, 10.5 cun proximal to the upper margin of the patella and 2 cun medial to the anterior midline of the thigh. It is 1 cun medial to Jiemeier (T 88.05) .
primary_indications: Primary: Severe common cold or flu with or without headache, high fever and chills
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 1 - 2 cun . Slow insertion is recommended.

name: Ganmen (T 33.11)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.11 Ganmen , is on the SI channel, 6 cun proximal to the wrist crease.
primary_indications: Primary: All hepatic disorders: Acute hepatitis, gallbladder disorders, insufficient bile secretion, hypochondriac pain Inner thigh pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Acute or chronic enteritis, chest stuffiness or pain
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun . Needling this point will immediately relieve the bitter taste in the mouth and pain in the hepatic/hypochondriac area. Turning the needle to the right will relieve chest pain associated with hepatitis, while turning needle to the left will relieve intestinal/abdominal pain. Needle the left side when treating acute hepatitis.

name: Guangming (T 77.28)
location: This point is on the KI channel and 1 cun posterior and 2 cun proximal to the tip of the medial malleolus. It is 2 cun proximal to Taixi (KI 3) , which is in the depression midway between the tip of the medial malleolus and the attachment of the Achilles tendon. Some references state that this point overlaps with Fuliu (KI 7) or Jiaoxin (KI 8) .
primary_indications: Primary: All eye disorders: cataract, eye soreness, eye pain, dry eyes, eye tiredness, astigmatism, lazy eye, floaters, double vision, etc.
secondary_indications: Secondary: Post-stroke hemiplegia
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side. This point can also be bled.

name: Gucier (T 44.22)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.22* Gucier , is on the LI channel, 4 cun proximal to Quchi (LI 11) , 2 cun above Guciyi (T 44.21)* .
primary_indications: Primary: Bone spurs, spine pain, traumatic injury of the vertebrae
techniques: Needle to touch the bone.

name: Gucisan (T 44.23)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.23* Gucisan , is on the LI channel, 6 cun proximal to Quchi (LI 11) , 2 cun above Gucier (T 44.22)* .
primary_indications: Primary: Bone spurs, spine pain, traumatic injury of the vertebrae
techniques: Needle to touch the bone.

name: Guciyi (T 44.21)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.21* Guciyi , is on the LI channel, 2 cun proximal to Quchi (LI 11) , which is on the lateral end of the transverse cubital crease.
primary_indications: Primary: Bone spur, spine pain, traumatic injury of the vertebrae
techniques: Needle to touch the bone.

name: Guguan (T 22.24)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.24* Guguan , is on the palmar aspect of the hand, 0.5 cun distal and 0.5 cun radial to Daling (PC 7) .
primary_indications: Primary: Heel spur, plantar fasciitis Pain, inflammation, and heat sensation in the uterus Hemiplegia, sciatica, bone spur causing pinched nerve and neuralgia Duodenal ulcer Excess uric acid in the body, food poisoning, drug poisoning
techniques: Needle perpendicularly or obliquely 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Haibao (T 66.01)
location: This point is on the SP channel in between Yinbai (SP 1) and Dadu (SP 2) on the border of the red and white skin.
primary_indications: Primary: Inguinal hernia Conjunctivitis, canthus pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Vaginitis Thumb and index finger pain
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun . Needle the side contralateral to the area of pain. For example, needle the right toe for left thumb pain.

name: Hou E Jiu (T VT.01)
location: 9 points total Point 1, or center point, is on the thyroid cartilage or over the Adams apple. Points 2 and 3 are 1.5 cun lateral to Point 1, one on each side. They overlap with Renying (ST 9) . Points 4, 5, 6 are 1 cun superior to Points 1, 2, 3. Points 7, 8, 9 are 1.5 cun inferior to Points 1, 2, 3. Two of the points are close to Shuitu (ST 10) .
primary_indications: Primary: Sore throat, ticklish throat, tonsilitis, thyroiditis, Mei he qi (plum-pit qi)
techniques: Pinch the skin when bleeding these points to avoid unnecessary injury.

name: Houhui (T 1010.06)
location: This point overlaps with Houding (GV 19) , which is 5.5 cun directly above the midpoint of the posterior hairline.
primary_indications: Primary: Headache, dizziness Tuberculosis of the bone Thoracic vertebrae pain, lumbar pain, and tailbone pain (especially effective for T12, L1, L2) Post-stroke complications, hemiplegia, numbness, loss of speech due to wind-stroke
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun

name: Houjian (T 33.19)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.19* Houjian , is in between the LI and TH channels, 2 cun distal and 1 cun ulnar to Quchi (LI 11) , which is on the lateral end of the transverse cubital crease.
primary_indications: Primary: Sore throat, inflammation of the throat, common cold, cough
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Houjian (T 44.29)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point Houjian has been renumbered to T 33.19. It was initially numbered incorrectly in the 44.xx zone. The location of this point is on the forearm, and therefore, is in the 33.xx zone. Please see Houjian (T 33.19)* for point information.

name: Houxin (T DT.11)
location: 20 points total The first 6 points are on the spine, below the spinous process of T4 to T9. 4 of the 6 points overlap with Shendao (GV 11) , Lingtai (GV 10) , Zhiyang (GV 9) , Jinsuo (GV 8) . The second set of 8 points is 1.5 cun lateral to the spinous process of T4 to T7 (4 points on each side). The third set of 6 points is 3 cun lateral to the spinous process of T4 to T6 (3 points on each side). They overlap with Gaohuangshu (BL 43) , Shentang (BL 44) , Yixi (BL 45) .
primary_indications: Primary: Goat's hair malignant, deep-rooted boils, carbuncles, furuncles Cardiac insufficiency Gastrointestinal disorders Acute heart failure Severe common cold
techniques: This point can be bled. Pinch the skin first prior to pricking for blood.

name: Houzhi (T 44.05)
location: On the posterior of the upper arm, this Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.05 Houzhi , is on the TH channel, 1 cun proximal to Fuding (T 44.04) , 8 cun proximal to the olecranon.
primary_indications: Primary: Hypertension, headache
secondary_indications: Secondary: Neck pain, facial paralysis Coronary heart disease, arteriosclerosis Bacterial infection, delayed wound healing, dermatological disorders
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 1 cun , or obliquely 1 - 1.5 cun .

name: Houzhui (T 44.02)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.02 Houzhui , is on the TH channel, 2.5 cun proximal to the olecranon along the posterior edge of the humerus.
primary_indications: Primary: Subluxation or dislocation of the spine, vertebral pain, distension and swelling, low back pain Nephritis Bronchitis
secondary_indications: Secondary: Hypertension Thirst, dry mouth, nighttime cough in the elderly
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun along the side of the bone or touching the bone.

name: Huaguer (T 55.03)
location: This is a two-point set on the sole of the foot between the 2 nd and the 3 rd metatarsals. The two points are 1 cun and 1.5 cun posterior from the web margin, approximately opposite to Xiangu (ST 43) .
primary_indications: Primary: Finger weakness, arm pain, inability to lift the arm
secondary_indications: Secondary: Digestive disorders
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun .

name: Huagusan (T 55.04)
location: This point is on the sole of the foot between the 3 rd and the 4 th metatarsals, 2 cun posterior from the web margin, opposite to Muliu (T 66.06) .
primary_indications: Primary: Back pain, sciatica, spine pain, eye disorders
techniques: Needle 0.5  1 cun .

name: Huagusi (T 55.05)
location: This point is on the sole of the foot, between the 4th and 5th metatarsals, 1.5 cun posterior to the web margin, opposite to Diwuhui (GB 42) .
primary_indications: Primary: Sciatica
secondary_indications: Secondary: Pain of the spine Abdominal pain, stomach pain Bleeding disorders
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun .

name: Huaguyi (T 55.02)
location: This is a four-point set on the sole of the foot between the 1st and 2nd metatarsals. The first point is 0.5 cun from the web margin, opposite to Xingjian (LR 2) . The rest are 1 cun , 1.5 cun , and 2 cun from the web margin on the same line. The third point is opposite to Taichong (LR 3) .
primary_indications: Primary: Face, ear, nose, and eye problems: Infection, conjunctivitis, red eyes, tearing of eyes or sensitivity to wind, photophobia, supraorbital pain, toothache, tinnitus, loss of hearing, sinus pain
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun .

name: Huanchao (T 11.06)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.06 Huanchao , is located on the palmar aspect of the ring finger, at the center along the ulnar aspect of the middle phalanx (line E).
primary_indications: Primary: Any reproductive and gynecological disorders Menstrual disorders (such as early, late, irregular, painful, profuse or scanty bleeding, clots) Vaginal discharge, yeast infection, genital swelling, cervicitis, lower abdominal pain, genital itching Infertility, fallopian tube blockage, malposition of the uterus, threatened miscarriage Uterine myoma, tumor, cancer, cysts Frequent urination
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.3 cun . The effect to treat the KI channel is enhanced when the needle tip touches the bone. Alternatively, it can also be needled from the dorsal aspect of the phalange, adjacent to the edge of the bone (cutting or shaving the bone technique).

name: Huo Er (T 99.03)
location: This point is on the superior crus of antihelix, at the level of the superior border of the inferior crus of antihelix. It is approximately at the same location as the auricular Hip Joint Point in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
primary_indications: Primary: Cardiovascular weakness, palpitation, dyspnea Knee pain, pain in the extremities
techniques: Use thinnest gauge possible and needle 0.1 to 0.2 cun .

name: Huobao (T 55.01)
location: This point overlaps with the extra point Duyin , which is on the plantar aspect of the 2nd toe, at the midpoint of the transverse crease of the DIP joint. There are discrepancies on the exact location of this point among different sources, therefore palpate for the ah shi point near the location described above for best results.
primary_indications: Primary: Angina, heart attack Retention of placenta, difficult labor
secondary_indications: Secondary: Hepatic disorders Red or white vaginal discharge, irregular menstruation Hernia
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun to touch the bone. This point can be bled, especially for angina.

name: Huochang (T 88.43)*
location: This point is on the BL channel, 10 cun inferior to the midpoint of the inferior gluteal crease, or 4 cun superior to Weizhong (BL 40) , which is in the center of the popliteal fossa.
primary_indications: Primary: Bone spurs (especially in the neck), back pain, sciatica Hemorrhoids Coronary heart disease
secondary_indications: Secondary: Upper back pain, occipital pain, neck tightness and pain, migraine, nervous headache Hemiplegia Chest tightness and pressure Nephritis
techniques: Needle 1 - 2.5 cun . This point can also be bled.

name: Huochuan (T 33.04)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.04 Huochuan , overlaps with Zhigou (TH 6) , which is located 3 cun proximal to the wrist crease in between the radius and the ulna.
primary_indications: Primary: Constipation Palpitations, chest pain that may radiate to the back, chest stuffiness, chest oppression, radiating spasms or cramps of the forearm or hand, radiating finger numbness
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun . Needle deeper to penetrate the PC channel for cardiovascular disorders.

name: Huofu (T 88.41)*
location: This point is on the BL channel, 3 cun inferior to the midpoint of the inferior gluteal crease.
primary_indications: Primary: Bone spurs (especially in the neck), back pain, sciatica Hemorrhoids Coronary heart disease
secondary_indications: Secondary: Upper back pain, occipital pain, neck tightness and pain, migraines, nervous headache Hemiplegia Chest tightness and pressure Nephritis
techniques: Needle 1 - 2.5 cun . This point can also be bled.

name: Huofuhai (T 33.07)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.07 Huofuhai , is on the TH channel close to Shousanli (LI 10) , 8.5 cun proximal to the wrist, and 2 cun proximal to Huoshan (T 33.06) on the muscular prominence of the dorsal forearm.
primary_indications: Primary: Common cold, cough, asthma, sinusitis Sciatica, coldness of the knees, soreness of the back and legs
secondary_indications: Secondary: Anti-aging point, anemia, dizziness, blurry vision, over exertion, fatigue, exhaustion
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1.5 cun . When needling for exhaustion and anti-aging, do not needle the point for more than 10 minutes. After removing the needle, use acupressure afterward to continue stimulating the point. It is also appropriate to apply moxibustion to this point.

name: Huoju (T 66.11)
location: This point overlaps with Gongsun (SP 4) , which is located on the medial side of the foot, in the depression distal and inferior to the base of the first metatarsal bone.
primary_indications: Primary: Hypertension: Headache, distension in the head, limited range of motion of the neck Numbness of the hand and fingers, weakness of the limbs, fatigue Palpations, dizziness, heart failure
secondary_indications: Secondary: Blurred vision, soreness of the eyelids, eye pain due to increased pressure in the eyes Post-stroke delirium, meningitis, brain tumor, neurasthenia
techniques: Perpendicular insertion 0.5 - 0.8 cun along the bone. This point can also be bled. Bleed dark veins nearby to invigorate qi and blood circulation, resuscitate the brain, and open the orifices.

name: Huolian (T 66.10)
location: This point overlaps with Taibai (SP 3) . Some sources state this point is 0.5 cun proximal to Taibai (SP 3) .
primary_indications: Primary: Hypertension leading to dizziness, blurred vision, palpitations, fatigue, weakness of the limbs, frontal headache
secondary_indications: Secondary: Brain tumor, meningitis
techniques: Perpendicular insertion 0.5 - 0.8 cun along the bone.

name: Huoliang (T 88.42)*
location: This point is on the BL channel, 7 cun inferior to the midpoint of the inferior gluteal crease.
primary_indications: Primary: Bone spurs (especially in the neck), back pain, sciatica Hemorrhoids Coronary heart disease
secondary_indications: Secondary: Upper back pain, occipital pain, neck tightness and pain, migraine, nervous headache Hemiplegia Chest tightness and pressure Nephritis
techniques: Needle 1 - 2.5 cun . This point can also be bled.

name: Huoling (T 33.05)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.05 Huoling , is on the TH channel, 5 cun proximal to the wrist, and 2 cun proximal to Huochuan (T 33.04) .
primary_indications: Primary: Chest pain, chest oppression, chest distension with radiating spasms or cramps of the forearm or hand, radiating finger numbness GB channel sciatica
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1 cun . Needle deeper to penetrate the PC channel for cardiovascular disorders. Needle contralateral to the affected side.

name: Huoquan (T 88.16)
location: This point is on the LR channel, 4.5 cun distal to Minghuang (T 88.12) , which is at the center of the midline of the medial thigh.
primary_indications: Primary: Jaundice, dizziness and blurry vision due to Liver imbalance, cholecystitis Upper back pain, heel pain, spinal pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Liver spots Epilepsy Elevated white blood cell
techniques: Needle 1.5 - 2 cun .

name: Huosan (T 66.12)
location: This point is on the KI channel and overlaps with Rangu (KI 2) . Some sources state this point is 0.5 cun proximal to Rangu (KI 2) .
primary_indications: Primary: Headache, head distension, neck pain, dizziness Brain tumor, meningitis
secondary_indications: Secondary: Blurred vision, conjunctivitis, canthus pain, declining vision Neurasthenia Low back pain
techniques: Perpendicular insertion 0.5 - 0.8 cun .

name: Huoshan (T 33.06)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.06 Huoshan , is on the TH channel, 6.5 cun proximal to the wrist, or 1.5 cun proximal to Huoling (T 33.05) .
primary_indications: Primary: Chest pain, chest oppression, chest distension Radiating spasms or cramps of the forearm or hand, radiating finger numbness, upper body paralysis Knee pain
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1.5 cun . Needle deeper to penetrate the PC channel for cardiovascular disorders.

name: Huoxi (T 11.16)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.16 Huoxi , overlaps with Shaoze (SI 1) , which is on the ulnar corner of the little fingernail (line F).
primary_indications: Primary: Psychological disorders ( shen disturbance) with phlegm misting the Heart or anger, anxiety, depression Medial knee pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Rheumatic heart disease, angina, mitral valve obstruction Shoulder pain, frozen shoulder Back pain, ankle pain, arthritis, rheumatoid arthritis
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun . Needle bilaterally to treat emotional and psychological conditions.

name: Huoying (T 66.03)
location: This point overlaps with Xingjian (LR 2) , which is between the 1st and 2nd toes, proximal to the margin of the web at the junction of the red and white skin.
primary_indications: Primary: Myocardial infarction (emergency point for syncope) Chin pain, jaw pain, TMJ, teeth grinding from stress, difficulty opening the mouth
secondary_indications: Secondary: Palpitation, vertigo, dizziness, fright, coma, unconsciousness, tinnitus Tumors of the uterus, uterine myomas, retained placenta, fibroids, inflammation of the uterus Knee swelling Eye pain Dysuria
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side. Visible veins near this point can be bled. Bleeding this point can be helpful for knee swelling, eye pain, and dysuria.

name: Huozhi (T 88.15)
location: This point is on the LR channel, 1.5 cun distal to Minghuang (T 88.12) , which is at the center of the midline of the medial thigh.
primary_indications: Primary: Jaundice, dizziness and blurry vision due to Liver imbalance, cholecystitis, cirrhosis Upper back pain
techniques: Needle 1.5 - 2.5 cun .

name: Huozhu (T 66.04)
location: This point overlaps with Taichong (LR 3) , which is on the dorsum of the foot in the depression distal to the junction of the 1st and 2nd metatarsal bones.
primary_indications: Primary: Cardiac disorders: myocardial infarction, heart disease leading to headache Liver or gastrointestinal diseases Neurasthenia Pain and numbness of the hands and feet Gynecological disorders: Inflammation or tumors of the uterus, fibroids and myomas, breech presentation, difficult labor, retained placenta, abnormal uterine bleeding, and lin zheng (dysuria syndrome)
secondary_indications: Secondary: Sore throat Headache, supraorbital nerve pain, epilepsy, facial paralysis Swollen bones Extreme fatigue Non-infectious urinary pain
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.8 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side. Visible veins near this point can be bled.

name: Jianfeng (T 44.31)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.31* Jianfeng , is 0.5 cun inferior to Jianyu (LI 15) , which is in the depression of the anterior superior portion of the shoulder on the m. deltoideus.
primary_indications: Primary: Hypertension Hyperhidrosis Breast cancer, breast tumor, fibrocystic breast disorder, breast pain, nipple pain Hemiplegia, numbness and bi zheng (painful obstruction syndrome) of the arms or half of the body, thrombosis
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 0.8 cun or obliquely downward 0.8 cun .

name: Jiangyadian (T 99.15)*
location: This is a three-point set at the lower tragus area. It is approximately between the auricular Adrenal Gland and Vision 1 points in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
primary_indications: Primary: High blood pressure
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.3 cun .

name: Jianzhong (T 44.06)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.06 Jianzhong , is on the LI channel, 2.5 cun distal to the acromion joint, on the midpoint of the deltoid muscle.
primary_indications: Primary: Arthritis of the knee, knee sprain, knee pain Hemiplegia Neurasthenia Arteriosclerosis, high cholesterol, coronary artery disease, palpitations Skin diseases (especially in the neck and arm area), boils, carbuncles
secondary_indications: Secondary: Back pain, sciatica, medial ankle and foot pain, xing bi (mobile painful obstruction) and arthritis and pain in multiple joints, shoulder pain, frozen shoulder, arm pain, weakness of the lower limbs, medial ankle pain Infantile paralysis, post-polio syndrome Epistaxis
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1 cun . In general, needle contralateral to the affected side. Needle on the same side as the affected area when treating skin conditions, hemiplegia, polio, and shoulder pain.

name: Jiazhuangxianzhong (T 99.19)*
location: This is a three-point set on the posterior ear lobe. The three points are vertically and evenly spaced along the medial end of the ear lobe. They are approximately at the same locations as the auricular Smart Point, Deep Sleep Point, and Be Happy Point in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
primary_indications: Primary: Goiter Palpitation
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 cun .

name: Jie (T 88.28)
location: This point is on the ST channel,1.5 cun superior and 0.3 cun medial to the superior lateral corner of the patella, near Liangqiu (ST 34) .
primary_indications: Primary: Fainting needle, swelling of needled area or lingering pain from acupuncture or injection, pain from physical trauma, emotional trauma or exhaustion Black tinge on the face from toxin from overuse of medication or drugs Pain, numbness, soreness from excessive mental stimulation/stress or exhaustion
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun slowly and stimulate softly. Needle should be removed when pain is relieved. Do not retain the needles for more than 8 minutes.

name: Jiemeier (T 88.05)
location: This point is on the SP channel, 10.5 cun proximal to the upper margin of the patella and 1 cun medial to the anterior midline of the thigh. It is 2.5 cun proximal to Jiemeiyi (T 88.04) .
primary_indications: Primary: All gynecological disorders: Vaginitis, inflammation of the uterus, uterine tumor, irregular menstruation, menorrhagia, lower pelvic pain, genital itching, red or white vaginal discharge (non-bacterial type), fallopian tube blockage
secondary_indications: Secondary: Gastric hemorrhage with tarry stools, lower abdominal pain, intestinal pain
techniques: Needle 1 - 2.5 cun bilaterally.

name: Jiemeisan (T 88.06)
location: This point is on the SP channel, 13 cun proximal to the upper margin of the patella and 1 cun medial to the anterior midline of the thigh. It is 2.5 cun proximal to Jiemeier (T 88.05) .
primary_indications: Primary: All gynecological disorders: Vaginitis, inflammation of the uterus, uterine tumor, irregular menstruation, menorrhagia, lower pelvic pain, genital itching, red or white vaginal discharge (non-bacterial type), fallopian tube blockage
secondary_indications: Secondary: Gastric hemorrhage with tarry stools, lower abdominal pain, intestinal pain
techniques: Needle 1 - 2.5 cun bilaterally.

name: Jiemeiyi (T 88.04)
location: This point overlaps with Jimen (SP 11) , which is on the SP channel, 8 cun proximal to the upper margin of the patella and 1 cun medial to the anterior midline of the thigh.
primary_indications: Primary: All gynecological disorders: Vaginitis, inflammation of the uterus, uterine tumor, fallopian tube blockage, irregular menstruation, menorrhagia, lower pelvic pain, genital itching, red or white vaginal discharge (non-bacterial type)
secondary_indications: Secondary: Gastric hemorrhage with tarry stools, lower abdominal pain, intestinal pain
techniques: Needle 1 - 2.5 cun bilaterally.

name: Jin Er (T 99.05)
location: On the posterior of the ear, this point is on the upper 1/3 of the superior edge of the dorsal helix. It is approximately at the same location as the top point of the auricular Three Shoulder Points in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
primary_indications: Primary: Sciatica due to Lung deficiency, scoliosis Allergy, common cold, rhinitis
techniques: Use thinnest gauge possible and needle 0.1 to 0.2 cun .

name: Jin Lin (T DT.09)
location: 6 points total These points are 6 cun lateral to the spinous process of T4 to T6 (3 points on each side). 2 of the 4 points overlap with Tianzong (SI 11) .
primary_indications: Primary: Sciatica due to arteriosclerosis, thigh pain

name: Jin Wu (T VT.03)
location: 5 points total The first point is on the midline of the sternum, level with the 2 nd ICS and overlaps Zigong (CV 19) . Each subsequent point is 1 cun inferior to the previous one, totaling 5 points.
primary_indications: Primary: Any digestive disorders, bloating, food poisoning with abdominal pain but no vomiting Hypochondriac pain, rib pain, flank pain Trachea blockage, tracheitis Various  " sha " syndromes
techniques: This point can be bled.

name: Jing Zhi (T DT.08)
location: 4 points total These points are 6 cun lateral to the spinous process of T2 and T3 (2 points on each side). 2 of the 4 points overlap with Bingfeng (SI 12) .
primary_indications: Primary: Lower leg tightness, distension, pain.

name: Jinqianshang (T 88.24)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 2.5 cun superior to thesuperior lateral corner of the patella or 1.5 cun superior to Jinqianxia (T 88.23) .
primary_indications: Primary: Lung deficiency and Liver weakness patterns Protrusion of the sternum, shoulder pain Headache, epilepsy Indigestion Dermatological disorders, skin allergy
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun .

name: Jinqianxia (T 88.23)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 1 cun superior to the superior lateral corner of the patella.
primary_indications: Primary: Lung deficiency and Liver weakness patterns Protrusion of the sternum, shoulder pain Headache, epilepsy Indigestion Dermatological disorders, skin allergy
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun .

name: Jinyingshang (T 88.33)*
location: This point is 2 cun proximal and 0.5 cun posterior to Fengshi (GB 31) , which is 7 cun proximal to the transverse popliteal crease.
primary_indications: Primary: Toxic poisoning from medication, food poisoning, acute gastroenteritis, pain throughout the body Emergency point for any acute condition
techniques: Needle 1.5 - 3 cun .

name: Jinyingxia (T 88.34)*
location: This point is 4 cun proximal and 0.5 cun posterior to Fengshi (GB 31) , which is 7 cun proximal to the transverse popliteal crease.
primary_indications: Primary: Toxic poisoning from medication, food poisoning, acute gastroenteritis, pain throughout the body Emergency point for any acute condition
techniques: Needle 1.5 - 3 cun .

name: Jiu Hou (T DT.06)
location: 18 points total The first set of 6 points is 1.5 cun lateral to the spinous process of T2 to T4 (3 points on each side). They overlap with Fengmen (BL 12) , Feishu (BL 13) , Jueyinshu (BL 14) . The second set of 8 points is 3 cun lateral to the spinous process of T1 to T4 (4 points on each side). 6 of the 8 points overlap with Fufen (BL 41) , Pohu (BL 42) , Gaohuangshu (BL 43) . The third set of 4 points is 6 cun lateral to the spinous process of T2 to T3 (2 points on each side). 2 of the 4 points overlap with Bingfeng (SI 12) .
primary_indications: Primary:  "Seventy-two types of Sha Syndrome": The type of Sha Syndrome this point is best at treating is rash with red dot eruptions that are extremely itchy.

name: Libai (T 44.12)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.12 Libai , is in between the LU and LI channels, 1 cun inferior and 1 cun anterior to the center of the deltoid muscle. It is in the natural depression on the anterior edge of the deltoid muscle.
primary_indications: Primary: Underarm odor, body odor
secondary_indications: Secondary: Excessive perspiration Lateral leg or calf pain, foot pain or sprain Post-polio syndrome
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Linggu (T 22.05)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.05 Linggu , is located on the LI channel, on the dorsal aspect of the hand, at the junction between the 1st and 2nd metacarpal bones, proximal to Hegu (LI 4) . This point is directly opposite to Chongxian (T 22.02) .
primary_indications: Primary: Pain and paresthesia Back pain, low back pain, sciatica, acute back sprain, sciatica, frozen shoulder, neck pain, knee pain, hemiplegia, numbness of limbs, weakness of the lower legs, bone swelling, heel pain, bone pain, facial paralysis, migraine, groin pain, headache, arm pain, elbow pain Any gynecological and menstrual disorder Amenorrhea, irregular menstruation, dysmenorrhea, difficult labor, insufficient lactation Any digestive disorder Poor appetite, indigestion, abdominal distension, enteritis, vomiting, diarrhea, duodenal ulcer, stomach ulcer, intestinal pain, rectal prolapse, thirst, diabetes, xiao ke (wasting and thirsting) syndrome Any disorder of the face and head Eyes, ears, nose, and throat disorders: tinnitus, hearing difficulties, dizziness, any eye disorder Any strange or chronic disorder that is unresponsive to regular treatments
secondary_indications: Secondary: Urinary disorders: enuresis, polyuria, dysuria, incontinence, urinary tract infection, nephritis, frequent urination Respiratory disorders: cough, common cold, sore throat, fever, headache with aversion to wind, pneumonia, emphysema, lung cancer, fluid in the lungs, difficult respiration, difficult exhalation, chronic laryngitis with tickling and urge to cough, post-meningitis symptoms Various types of sweating, including night sweating, profuse sweating, sweaty hands Arrhythmia
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 1 - 1.5 cun . Patient should move his/her back while needles are being manipulated. Needle contralateral to the affected area. Avoid the radial artery when needling. When treating problems involving the bone, needles should be inserted along the edge of the bone or touching the bone for optimal effectiveness.

name: Liukuai (T 1010.16)
location: This point is 1.4 cun lateral to Renzhong (GV 26) , which is at the junction of the upper and middle third of the philtrum.
primary_indications: Primary: Urinary stones, urinary tract infection
secondary_indications: Secondary: Penis pain
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.3 cun or subcutaneously outwards 0.5 - 1.5 cun . This point can also be bled.

name: Liuwan (T 66.08)
location: This point overlaps with Xiaxi (GB 43) , which is between the 4th and 5th metatarsal bones, 0.5 cun proximal to the web margin. Some books state this point is 0.5 cun proximal to Xiaxi (GB 43) .
primary_indications: Primary: Migraines Bleeding due to trauma: injuries, knife wounds, tooth extraction
secondary_indications: Secondary: Meniere's disease, tinnitus Hemiplegia
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Luotong (T 44.14)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.14 Luotong , is on the SI channel, 7 cun proximal to the elbow.
primary_indications: Primary: Hypertension, arteriosclerosis Dizziness, fatigue, low back soreness
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun along the bone.

name: Majinshui (T 1010.13)
location: This point overlaps with Quanliao (SI 18) , which is located directly below the outer canthus, in the depression at the lower border of the zygomatic bone.
primary_indications: Primary: Kidney stones Nephritis Rhinitis Acute back sprain, back pain, acute chest and rib pain, pain of the ribs when breathing
secondary_indications: Secondary: Edema
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.3 cun If the pain is immediately relieved after the needle is inserted, the point location is correct. If there is bleeding after the needle is pulled out, then the location is incorrect.

name: Makuaishui (T 1010.14)
location: This point is on the SI channel, 0.4 cun inferior to Quanliao (SI 18) , at the level of the lower border of the ala nasi. Quanliao (SI 18) is located directly below the outer canthus, in the depression at the lower border of the zygomatic bone.
primary_indications: Primary: Urinary stones Nephritis, cystitis, frequent urination Spine pain, back pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Edema Rhinitis
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.3 cun

name: Menjin (T 66.05)
location: This point overlaps with Xiangu (ST 43) , which is in the depression distal to the junction of the 2nd and 3rd metatarsal bones.
primary_indications: Primary: Gastrointestinal disorders: gastritis, enteritis, appendicitis, colitis, abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhea, dysentery, rectal prolapse, peritonitis Lower abdominal pain before or after menstruation
secondary_indications: Secondary: Migraine, headaches Inflammation of the uterus and ovaries
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun . Needle towards or penetrate through to Yongquan (KI 1) to treat vertex headaches. This point can also be bled. Bleeding this point is more effective than needling when treating migraines.

name: Minghuang (T 88.12)
location: This point is on the LR channel, at the center of the midline of the medial thigh.
primary_indications: Primary: Any hepatic and gallbladder disorders, especially hepatitis, liver cirrhosis Impaired liver function leading to fatigue and exhaustion, vertigo, eye pain, blurry vision, gallstones, cholecystitis, liver spots, hypochondriac pain, indigestion, Mnire's disease Leukemia, elevated white blood cell count
secondary_indications: Secondary: Multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, chorea Liver qi stagnation leading to nervousness, anxiety, insomnia Low back soreness, bone swelling, spine periostitis, xing bi (mobile painful obstruction), lateral arm pain from elbow to wrist Leukorrhea, irregular menstruation Bleeding gums, anemia Urinary retention, urinary incontinence High blood pressure, low blood pressure Hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia Post-stroke complications, hemiplegia Enlarged heart, chest pain
techniques: Needle 1 - 3 cun perpendicularly towards the femur. Superficial depth addresses KI, middle depth addresses the LR, and deep level needling addresses the HT.

name: Mu (T 11.17)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.17 Mu , is a two-point set on the palmar aspect of the index finger, evenly distributed along the ulnar margin of the proximal phalangeal bone (line D). Divide the proximal phalanx into thirds, and locate these two points at 1/3 and 2/3 of the distance between the MCP and PIP joints. Some sources indicate this is a three-point group rather than a two-point group.
primary_indications: Primary: Common cold, runny nose, sinusitis, rhinitis Dry or watery eyes, tearing with exposure to wind Itchy skin, sweaty hands, dry, cracked skin on the fingers or rough palms or hands, dermatitis of the hands, peeling of palm, fungal infection of the hand, general itching due to wind Right hypochondriac pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: LR channel disorders: Liver qi stagnation, Liver yang rising, Wood overacting on Earth symptoms such as stomach pain, high cholesterol, short temper, dry mouth, insomnia
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.2 - 0.3 cun adjacent to the edge of the bone towards the back aspect of the hand. Needle the affected side when treating skin disorders. With all other conditions, needle the side opposite to the problem. For bloating due to Liver overacting on Spleen, needle both sides. This point can also be bled.

name: Muchang (T 88.40)*
location: This point is 10 cun inferior and 2 cun medial to the midpoint of the inferior gluteal crease, or 4 cun superior and 2 cun medial to Weizhong (BL 40) , which is in the middle of the popliteal fossa.
primary_indications: Primary: Sciatica Coronary heart disease
secondary_indications: Secondary: Lower back pain, upper or mid back pain, leg pain, headache Rheumatoid arthritis, bone spurs Hepatitis Dysmenorrhea, prostate enlargement Constipation, diarrhea, hemorrhoid Cystitis, urinary tract infection
techniques: Needle 1 - 3 cun . This point can also be bled.

name: Mudou (T 66.07)
location: This point is on the dorsum of the foot, 0.5 cun proximal to the web margin between the 3rd and 4th toes.
primary_indications: Primary: Splenomegaly with palpable mass Hepatic disorders, gallbladder disorders (gallstones) Indigestion, fatigue
secondary_indications: Secondary: Polio, infantile paralysis
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 1 cun .

name: Muer (T 99.02)
location: This point is on the upper half of the posterior ear, 0.3 cun below the horizontal vein (middle transverse line).
primary_indications: Primary: Liver cirrhosis, hepatomegaly, fatigue due to liver dysfunction, hepatic pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Chronic gonorrhea
techniques: Use thinnest gauge possible and needle 0.1 to 0.2 cun . This point can also be bled.

name: Mufu (T 66.02)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 0.3 cun lateral to the center of the dorsal middle phalange of the 2nd toe.
primary_indications: Primary: All female reproductive disorders, especially red or white vaginal discharge Amenorrhea, fallopian tube blockage, inflammation of the uterus, infertility, abnormal menstruation, dysmenorrhea, etc.
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.4 cun along the bone.

name: Mufu (T 88.38)*
location: This point is 3 cun inferior and 2 cun medial to the midpoint of the inferior gluteal crease.
primary_indications: Primary: Sciatica Coronary heart disease
secondary_indications: Secondary: Lower back pain, upper or mid back pain, leg pain, headache Rheumatoid arthritis, bone spurs Hepatitis Dysmenorrhea, prostate enlargement Constipation, diarrhea, hemorrhoid Cystitis, urinary tract infection
techniques: Needle 1 - 3 cun . This point can also be bled.

name: Muguan (T 22.26)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.26* Muguan , is on the palmar aspect of the hand, 0.5 cun distal and 0.5 cun ulnar to Daling (PC 7) .
primary_indications: Primary: Epigastric pain, hypochondriac pain, back pain, chest stuffiness, peritonitis Sciatica, leg pain, heel pain, whole body joint pain, bone swelling, osteoma Jaundice, hyperuricemic toxicity, food poisoning, drug poisoning Any gynecological disorders involving inflammation and heat
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun . Needle obliquely and distally up to 1.5 cun for disorders of the bone, including bone spurs.

name: Muhuang (T 88.47)*
location: This point is on the LR channel, 6 cun below the center of the midline of the medial thigh.
primary_indications: Primary: Any hepatic and gallbladder disorders such as jaundice, cholecystitis Bone spurs
secondary_indications: Secondary: Splenomegaly Low white blood cell count
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun .

name: Muhuo (T 11.10)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.10 Muhuo , is located on the dorsal aspect of the middle finger, at the center of the DIP joint (line G).
primary_indications: Primary: Post-stroke complications, hemiplegia Heart disorders
secondary_indications: Secondary: Calf pain (or feeling of coldness, tightness or distension of the lower leg), knee pain around Ququan (LR 8) , ankle pain after exposure to cold/icy water Headache
techniques: Needle superficially 0.1 - 0.2 cun and obliquely 15 degrees towards the ring finger. Never retain needles for more than 5 minutes. First treatment should be no more than 5 minutes, second treatment (5 days later) for 3 minutes, and last treatment (after 10 days) for 1 minute. This point can also be bled if the area appears dark or if it has surrounding dark veins. Needle or bleed contralateral to the affected side.

name: Muliang (T 88.39)*
location: This point is 7 cun inferior and 2 cun medial to the midpoint of the inferior gluteal crease.
primary_indications: Primary: Sciatica Coronary heart disease
secondary_indications: Secondary: Lower back pain, upper or mid back pain, leg pain, headache Rheumatoid arthritis, bone spurs Hepatitis Dysmenorrhea, prostate enlargement Constipation, diarrhea, hemorrhoid Cystitis, urinary tract infection
techniques: Needle 1 - 3 cun . This point can also be bled.

name: Muling (T 11.29)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.29* Muling , is located on the palmar aspect of the ring finger, along the radial margin of the PIP joint (line B).
primary_indications: Primary: Hepatic disorders: liver cirrhosis, hepatitis, liver cancer, intercostal pain, cholecystitis, biliary ascariasis
secondary_indications: Secondary: Wei zheng (atrophy syndrome) Hemiplegia
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.2 - 0.3 cun . This point can also be bled. It is most effective when dark blood or yellowish liquid is squeezed out.

name: Muliu (T 66.06)
location: This point is on the dorsum of the foot, 2 cun proximal to the web margin between the 3rd and 4th toes.
primary_indications: Primary: Splenomegaly Hepatic disorders, gallbladder disorders (gallstones) Leukemia Indigestion, fatigue
secondary_indications: Secondary: Polio, infantile paralysis Middle finger or ring finger pain or stiffness Pain, tumor in the clavicle and shoulder area TMJ, inner ear pain, headache
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 1 cun .

name: Muyan (T 11.20)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.20 Muyan , is a two-point set on the palmar aspect of the ring finger, evenly distributed along the ulnar margin of the middle phalangeal bone (line D). Divide the middle phalanx into thirds, and located these two points at 1/3 and 2/3 the distance between the PIP and DIP joints.
primary_indications: Primary: Hepatitis, hepatomegaly, liver cirrhosis Liver fire with irritability, restlessness, bitter taste in the mouth, hypochondriac pain, insomnia
secondary_indications: Secondary: Leg cramps
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.2 - 0.3 cun adjacent to the bone towards the dorsal aspect of the hand.

name: Muying (T 99.12)*
location: This point is on the cymba conchae, superior to the end of the helix crus. It is approximately at the same location as the auricular Hepatomegaly Area in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
primary_indications: Primary: Hepatomegaly
techniques: This point can also be bled.

name: Muzhi (T 1010.18)
location: This point overlaps with Xiaguan (ST 7) on the face, which is in the depression between the zygomatic arch and the mandibular notch when the mouth is closed.
primary_indications: Primary: Night crying in children, nightmares, night terrors Gallstones, gallbladder deficiency causing hysteria
secondary_indications: Secondary: Toothache (especially upper teeth) Weakness of the lower limbs in the elderly
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun This point can also be bled.

name: Neitongguan (T 88.29)
location: This point is 0.5 cun medial to Tongguan (T 88.01) , which is on the anterior midline of the thigh, 5 cun proximal to the upper margin of the patella, close to the ST channel.
primary_indications: Primary: Wind-stroke and post-stroke complications: hemiplegia, weakness of limbs, inability to raise the arm, speech impairment, transient ischemic attacks Cardiac disorders: palpitations, weakness of the heart, radiating shoulder pain, radiating upper back pain
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Neitongshan (T 88.30)
location: This point is 0.5 cun medial to Tongshan (T 88.02) , which is on the anterior midline of the thigh, 7 cun proximal to the upper margin of the patella, close to the ST channel.
primary_indications: Primary: Wind stroke and post-stroke complications: hemiplegia, weakness of limbs, inability to raise the arm, speech impairment Transient ischemic attacks Cardiac disorders: palpitations, weakness of the heart, radiating shoulder pain, radiating upper back pain
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 0.8 cun .

name: Neitongtian (T 88.31)
location: This point is 0.5 cun medial to Tongtian (T 88.03) , which is on the anterior midline of the thigh, 9 cun proximal to the upper margin of the patella, close to the ST channel.
primary_indications: Primary: Wind stroke and post-stroke complications: hemiplegia, weakness of limbs, inability to raise the arm, speech impairment Transient ischemic attacks Cardiac disorders: palpitations, weakness of the heart, radiating shoulder pain, radiating upper back pain
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 0.8 cun .

name: Pianjian (T 44.20)*
location: According to Henry McCann, this Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.20* Pianjian , is 1 cun horizontally posterior to Jianyu (LI 15) , which is anterior and inferior to the acromion in a depression found when the arm abducted. This point is closer to the TH channel. However, according to James Maher, this point is located at the midpoint of Jianfeng (T 44.31)* and Shangqu (T 44.16) . [ Jianfeng (T 44.31)* is located 0.5 cun inferior to Jianyu (LI 15) . Shangqu (T 44.16) is located on the lateral aspect of the upper arm, 1 cun posterior to the center of the deltoid muscle.]
primary_indications: Primary: Sciatica
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Pier (T 88.36)*
location: This point is close to the SP channel, 3.5 cun proximal and 1 cun medial to the superior medial corner of the patella, 2 cun proximal to Piyi (T 88.35)* .
primary_indications: Primary: Splenomegaly
secondary_indications: Secondary: Back pain
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun .

name: Pifu (T 99.14)*
location: This point is on the scapha next to Darwin's tubercle. It is approximately at the same location as the auricular Allergy Area in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
primary_indications: Primary: Urticaria and any dermatological condition or allergy
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 cun. This point can also be bled.

name: Pisan (T 88.37)*
location: This point is close to the SP channel, 5.5 cun proximal and 1 cun medial to the superior medial corner of the patella, 2 cun proximal to Pier (T 88.36)* .
primary_indications: Primary: Splenomegaly
secondary_indications: Secondary: Back pain
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun .

name: Piyi (T 88.35)*
location: This point is close to Xuehai (SP 10) , 1.5 cun proximal and 1 cun medial to the superior medial corner of the patella.
primary_indications: Primary: Splenomegaly
secondary_indications: Secondary: Back pain
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun .

name: Pizhong (T 11.18)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.18 Pizhong , is a two-point set on the palmar aspect of the middle finger, along the midline of the middle phalanx (line C). Divide the middle phalanx into thirds, and located these two points at 1/3 and 2/3 the distance between the PIP and DIP joints.
primary_indications: Primary: Disorders of the Spleen Splenomegaly, pancreatitis, splenitis, splenceratosis, abdominal bloating Chest and upper back pain, leg and toe pain
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.2 cun .

name: Qianhui (T 1010.05)
location: This point overlaps with Qianding (GV 21) , which is 3.5 cun directly above the midpoint of the anterior hairline.
primary_indications: Primary: Dizziness, blurry vision, headache, feeling of distension in the head Nervousness, neurasthenia Shock, syncope (resuscitation point)
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun

name: Qihu (T 77.26)
location: This point is a three-point set between the BL and the GB channels, behind the posterior border of the fibula and along the anterior border of the Achilles tendon. The points are 1.5 cun posterior to the lateral malleolus. The first point is 2 cun proximal to the lateral malleolus. The second point is 4 cun proximal to the lateral malleolus, or 2 cun proximal to the first point. The third point is 6 cun proximal to the lateral malleolus, or 2 cun proximal to the second point.
primary_indications: Primary: Neck pain, neck sprain, sternum pain, clavicle pain, rib pain, scapular pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Pleurisy
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun . Bleed any veins near these points prior to needling for best results.

name: Qihuang (T 88.14)
location: This point is on the LR channel, 3 cun distal to Minghuang (T 88.12) , which is at the center of the midline of the medial thigh.
primary_indications: Primary: Leukemia, elevated white blood cell count Any liver and gallbladder disorders, especially hepatitis, liver cirrhosis Impaired liver function leading to fatigue and exhaustion, vertigo, eye pain, blurry vision, gallstones, cholecystitis, liver spots, hypochondriac pain, indigestion, Mnire's disease Epilepsy
secondary_indications: Secondary: Multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, chorea Liver qi stagnation leading to nervousness, anxiety, insomnia Low back soreness, bone swelling, spine periostitis, xing bi (mobile painful obstruction), lateral arm pain from elbow to wrist, bone spurs Leukorrhea, irregular menstruation Bleeding gums, anemia Urinary retention, urinary incontinence High blood pressure, low blood pressure Hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia Post-stroke complications, hemiplegia Enlarged heart, chest pain
techniques: Needle 1 - 3 cun perpendicularly towards the femur. Superficial depth addresses KI, middle depth addresses the LR, and deep level needling addresses the HT.

name: Qijiao (T 33.02)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.02 Qijiao , is on the LI channel, 4 cun proximal to the wrist crease.
primary_indications: Primary: Gynecological disorders: Pelvic inflammatory disease, leucorrhea (white or red), irregular menstruation, fibroids, endometriosis, cervicitis, low libido, inability to reach orgasm, cervical cancer, ovarian cancer, lin zheng (dysuria syndrome), cystitis, UTI Rectal prolapse, hemorrhoids, chronic long-term constipation
secondary_indications: Secondary: Diarrhea, abdominal bloating and distension, colon cancer
techniques: Needle 15 degrees obliquely towards Yangxi (LI 5) , 0.2 - 0.5 cun. It is said that perpendicular needling yields no therapeutic effect.

name: Qikuai (T 1010.17)
location: This point overlaps with Dicang (ST 4) , which is lateral to the corner of the mouth, directly below the pupil of the eye.
primary_indications: Primary: Urinary stones, abdominal pain Facial paralysis Generalized weakness from LU deficiency
secondary_indications: Secondary: Hiccups
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.3 cun or thread the needle laterally 0.5 - 1.5 cun . This point can also be bled.

name: Qili (T 88.51)*
location: This point is 2 cun distal to Zhongjiuli (T 88.25) , which overlaps with Fengshi (GB 31) , in the center of the median line of the lateral thigh. This point overlaps Zhongdu (GB 32) .
primary_indications: Primary: All skin disorders Hemiplegia, leg pain, chest pain, back pain, nerve pain Respiratory disorders Abdominal distension, bloating, pain
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 2 - 3 cun .

name: Qimen (T 33.01)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.01 Qimen , is on the LI channel, 2 cun proximal to the wrist crease.
primary_indications: Primary: Gynecological disorders: Pelvic inflammatory disease, leucorrhea (white or red), irregular menstruation, fibroids, endometriosis, cervicitis, low libido, inability to reach orgasm, cervical cancer, ovarian cancer, lin zheng (dysuria syndrome), cystitis, UTI Hemorrhoids, rectal prolapse, chronic long-term constipation
secondary_indications: Secondary: Diarrhea, abdominal bloating and distension, colon cancer
techniques: Needle 15 degrees obliquely towards Yangxi (LI 5) , 0.2 - 0.5 cun . It is said that perpendicular needling yields no therapeutic effect.

name: Qixing (T DT.03)
location: 7 points total Point 1 is 1 cun superior to the center of the posterior hairline in the depression directly below the occipital protuberance. This point overlaps with Fengfu (GV 16) . Point 2 is at the center of the posterior hairline, 1 cun inferior to Point 1. Point 3 is 2 cun inferior to Point 2. Points 4 and 5 are 0.8 cun lateral and 0.8 cun inferior to Point 2, one on each side. Points 6 and 7 are 1 cun inferior to Points 4 and 5.
primary_indications: Primary: Vomiting, acute enteritis, summer-stroke Common cold with headache Fever (infantile) and internal wind conditions with spasms and tremors in children
techniques: This point can be bled. Pinch the skin first prior to pricking for blood. Be extra cautious in children not to injure the nerve of the brain which may lead to deafness or aphasia. Bleeding the first three points are usually sufficient to see results.

name: Qizheng (T 33.03)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.03 Qizheng , is on the LI channel, 6 cun proximal to the wrist crease.
primary_indications: Primary: Gynecological disorders: Pelvic inflammatory disease, leucorrhea (white or red), irregular menstruation, fibroids, endometriosis, cervicitis, low libido, inability to reach orgasm, cervical ancer, ovarian cancer, lin zheng (dysuria syndrome), cystitis, UTI Hemorrhoids, rectal prolapse, chronic long-term constipation
secondary_indications: Secondary: Diarrhea, abdominal bloating and distension, colon cancer
techniques: Needle 15 degrees obliquely towards Yangxi (LI 5) , 0.2 - 0.5 cun . It is said that perpendicular needling yields no therapeutic effect.

name: Quling (T 33.16)
