location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.16 Quling , overlaps with Chize (LU 5) , which is 0.5 cun radial to the biceps brachii tendon in the cubital fossa.
primary_indications: Primary: Asthma, cough and any excess condition of the Lung Elbow joint pain, tennis elbow, arthritis Digestive disorders, including vomiting and diarrhea Muscle spasm, tendon spasms Palpitations
secondary_indications: Secondary: Severe common cold/flu, excess nasal discharge, acute tonsillitis, pharyngitis, laryngitis Acute mastitis Thyroid nodule or swelling Intestinal cholera, liver cholera Cardiac failure, cardiac hypertrophy, angina, chest pain, radiating upper back pain
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun . Use a three-edged needle to bleed the dark veins close to this point. Bleeding dark veins in the cubital fossa can treat the following conditions: asthma, digestive disorders, heart disease, shoulder and upper extremity pain, common cold and sore throat.

name: Renhuang (T 77.21)
location: This point overlaps with Sanyinjiao (SP 6) , which is 3 cun directly above the tip of the medial malleolus along the posterior border of the tibia.
primary_indications: Primary: Kidney disorders: nephritis, edema, proteinuria Any urinary disorders: lin zheng (dysuria syndrome), xue lin (bloody dysuria), cystitis, nocturnal emission, ascites Kidney deficiency with impotence, premature ejaculation, spermatorrhea, back pain (chronic or deficiency)
secondary_indications: Secondary: Dysmenorrhea, post-partum urinary retention, post-tubal ligation complications Spine pain, neck pain Eye pain, dizziness Hand numbness, neurotic dermatitis Diarrhea, diabetes
techniques: Needle 1 - 2.5 cun .

name: Renshi (T 33.13)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.13 Renshi , is 4 cun proximal to the wrist crease on the LU or PC channel.
primary_indications: Primary: Asthma, cough Cardiac insufficiency, arrhythmia, heart disease, palpitation
secondary_indications: Secondary: Pain in the palm or fingers, upper back pain, frozen shoulder Proteinuria
techniques: Needle 0.5 cun for LU disorders, 1 cun for HT and KI disorders. Needle the side opposite to the affected area. Since this point is on or in between the PC or LU channel, select the PC channel when treating cardiovascular problems and use the LU channel when treating respiratory disorders.

name: Renzong (T 44.08)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.08 Renzong , overlaps with Shouwuli (LI 13) , which is 3 cun proximal to the cubital crease, in the depression between the lateral border of the humerus and the m. biceps brachii. Some sources indicate this point is 3 cun above the cubital crease on the LU channel.
primary_indications: Primary: Arm pain, hand pain, elbow pain Bloating
secondary_indications: Secondary: Foot pain, lower leg pain, medial knee pain Common cold, asthma Jaundice, gallbladder disorders Edema, splenomegaly
techniques: Needle 0.5 cun for common cold and asthma. Needle 0.8 cun for swollen limbs. Needle 1.2 cun for LR, GB, SP disorders. Needle location must be precise so as not to injure the biceps muscle or the humerus.

name: San Jiang (T DT.15)
location: 19 points total The first 7 points are on the spine at the level of L1 to S2. 3of the 7 points overlap with Xuanshu (GV 5) , Mingmen (GV 4) , Yaoyan gguan (GV 3) . The second set of 12 points is 3 cun lateral to the spine at the level of L2 to S2 (6 points on each side). 4 of the 12 points overlap with Zhishi (BL 52) and Baohuang (BL 53) .
primary_indications: Primary: Amenorrhea, pelvic inflammatory disease, uteritis Enteritis Acute back sprain, acute chest or rib pain with difficulty breathing

name: San Jin (T DT.07)
location: 6 points total These points are 3 cun lateral to the spinous process of T3 to T5 (3 points on each side). They overlap with Pohu (BL 42) , Gaohuangshu (BL 43) , Shentang (BL 44) .
primary_indications: Primary: Knee pain

name: Sanchaer (T 22.16)*
location: When making a fist, the Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.16 Sanchaer , is on the dorsal aspect of the hand, in the junction between the 3rd and 4th phalanges.
primary_indications: Primary: Sciatica, hemiplegia, numbness of the hands, numbness of the feet
secondary_indications: Secondary: Knee pain, acute back sprain Splenomegaly, pancreatitis Heart weakness
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun towards the wrist while the patient makes a fist. The needle should go in parallel to the skin of the dorsum of the hand.

name: Sanchasan (T 22.17)*
location: When making a fist, the Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.17 Sanchasan , is on the dorsal aspect of the hand, in the junction between the 4th and 5th phalanges.
primary_indications: Primary: Pain: sciatica, bone spurs, back pain, back sorenesss, back weakness, shoulder pain, leg pain Edema, edema from nephritis or other kidney diseases Severe common cold, dizziness
secondary_indications: Secondary: Diseases of the five senses, tinnitus Palpitations Urticaria Myasthenia gravis, heaviness or drop eyelid, redness and swelling or pain of the eyes, sore throat
techniques: Needle 1 - 1.5 cun towards the wrist while the patient makes a fist. The needle should go in parallel to the skin of the dorsum of the hand.

name: Sanchashenjing (T 99.16)*
location: This is a three-point set on the medial border of the ear lobe. The three points are spaced evenly from the intertragic notch to the bottom of the medial ear lobe. They are approximately at the same locations as the auricular Tooth Point, Neurasthenia Point, Anxious Point in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
primary_indications: Primary: Trigeminal neuralgia
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.2 cun .

name: Sanchayi (T 22.15)*
location: When making a fist, the Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.15 Sanchayi , is on the dorsal aspect of the hand, in the junction between the 2nd and 3rd phalanges.
primary_indications: Primary: Sciatica Orbital pain, keratitis, eye pain, degenerative optic nerve disorders
secondary_indications: Secondary: Shoulder pain, neck pain, back pain, lower back pain, hypochondriac pain, hemiplegia, wei zheng (atrophy syndrome) Epigastric, stomach pain Irregular menstruation Weak lung qi, weak wei (defensive) qi
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun towards the wrist while the patient makes a fist. Needle should go in parallel to the skin of the dorsum of the hand.

name: Sanling (T 44.18)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.18* Sanling , is a three-point set consisting of a central point 0.5 cun proximal to Quze (PC 3) , which is on the ulnar side of the tendon m. biceps brachii on the transverse crease of the elbow. The two others points are 0.5 cun radial and 0.5 cun ulnar to the first.
primary_indications: Primary: Acute heart attack, acute angina, chest stuffiness, chest oppression, chest tightness, chest pain radiating to the upper back Gaohuangshu (BL 43) area, difficulty breathing from insufficient oxygen to the heart
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun perpendicularly or obliquely. This point should be bled for optimal effect. Look for a dark vein or shadow to bleed. Squeezing out black blood will yield better effects than squeezing out red blood.

name: Sanlinger (T 88.49)*
location: This point is on the BL channel, 2 cun proximal to Weizhong (BL 40) , which is in the center of the popliteal fossa.
primary_indications: Primary: BL channel pain: Occipital headache, migraine, neck pain, upper back pain, back pain, sciatica, leg soreness, leg pain, leg spasm, leg cramp Chest stuffiness, chest oppression, chest tightness, coronary heart disorder
techniques: Needle 1 cun perpendicularly, or bleed the dark veins in this area.

name: Sanlingsan (T 88.50)*
location: This point is on the BL channel, 3 cun proximal to Weizhong (BL 40) , which is in the center of the popliteal fossa.
primary_indications: Primary: BL channel pain: Occipital headache, migraine, neck pain, upper back pain, back pain, sciatica, leg soreness, leg pain, leg spasm and cramps Chest stuffiness, chest oppression, chest tightness, coronary heart disorder
techniques: Needle 1 cun perpendicularly, or bleed the dark veins in this area.

name: Sanlingyi (T 88.48)*
location: This point is on the BL channel, 1 cun proximal to Weizhong (BL 40) , which is in the center of the popliteal fossa.
primary_indications: Primary: BL channel pain: Occipital headache, migraine, neck pain, upper back pain, back pain, sciatica, leg soreness, leg pain, leg spasms and cramps Chest stuffiness, chest oppression, chest tightness, coronary heart disorder
techniques: Needle 1 cun perpendicularly, or bleed the dark veins in this area.

name: Sanshen (T 44.27)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.27* Sanshen , is a three-point set on the TH channel, on the lateral aspect of the upper arm. These points are 1.5 cun , 2.5 cun , and 3.5 cun proximal to the olecranon when the elbow is flexed.
primary_indications: Primary: Kidney deficiency: Impotence, premature ejaculation Back soreness, back weakness
secondary_indications: Secondary: Kidney stone, chronic nephritis, proteinuria Dry throat, bronchitis, cough in the elderly Throat cancer, lung cancer
techniques: Needle 1 cun perpendicularly to tonify the Kidney. Needle obliquely and superiorly 0.5 cun when treating the throat and bronchitis.

name: Sansheng (T 55.07)*
location: This is a three-point set on the KI channel, on the midline of the sole, 1 cun , 2 cun , and 3 cun posterior to Yongquan (KI 1) .
primary_indications: Primary: Hypertension, high diastolic blood pressure, cerebral hemorrhage, cerebral thrombosis
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun .

name: Sanyan (T 11.21)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.21 Sanyan , is located on the palmar aspect of the ring finger, along the radial margin of the proximal phalangeal bone (line B). Divide the distance between the MCP and PIP joints into thirds, and locate this point at the distal third (closest to the PIP joint).
primary_indications: Primary: Fatigue, Spleen qi deficiency
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.3 cun along the edge of the bone.

name: Sanzhong (T 77.07)
location: This point is between the GB and ST channels, 7 cun proximal to the lateral malleolus and 1 cun anterior to the fibula. It is 2 cun above Erzhong (T 77.06) .
primary_indications: Primary: Hyperthyroidism (caused by heart disease), bulging of the eyes, enlarged thyroid, tonsillitis, liver disease, rib pain, teeth clenching at night, migraine Post-stroke complications, deviation of the eyes and mouth, TMJ, post-concussion symptoms Breast disorders: mastitis, fibrocystic breast disease, breast tumors, breast cancer, breast pain Spleen disorders: splenomegaly, abdominal mass Tumors and cancer: brain, breast, esophageal
secondary_indications: Secondary: Meningitis
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun . Needle the healthy side when treating TMJ or deviation of the eyes and mouth. This point can also be bled.

name: Shangbai (T 22.03)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.03 Shangbai , is located on the dorsal aspect of the hand between the index and middle fingers, 0.5 cun proximal to the MCP joints of these fingers.
primary_indications: Primary: Eye disorders: Conjunctivitis, keratitis, near-sightedness, eye soreness, eye swelling, eye itchiness, astigmatism, tearing upon exposure to wind, weakness or tired eyes from overuse
secondary_indications: Secondary: Sciatica, shoulder pain, arm pain, lateral side chest pain, weakness of the feet, ankle pain, ankle sprain, wrist pain Enteritis
techniques: Needle 1 cun . This point is most often needled bilaterally for optimal effect. Needle bilaterally for neck pain. Needle bilaterally and retain needles for 1 hour for itchy eyes. Needle the diseased side for wrist sprain. Needle the healthy side for weakness of the feet.

name: Shangchun (T 77.15)
location: This point overlaps with Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament when the knee is flexed. Some books state this point is at the lower mid or lateral ridge of the patella.
primary_indications: Primary: Lip pain, lip ulcer, lip swelling, mouth ulcer, tongue stiffness, difficulty speaking Thrush or oral candidiasis in children, yeast infection, vitiligo around the mouth or genitals
secondary_indications: Secondary: Oral herpes, genital herpes
techniques: Bleed to expel dark blood and to purge heat for immediate results.

name: Shanggao (T 22.21)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.21 Shanggao , is on the palmar aspect of the hand, along the HT channel between the 4th and 5th metacarpal bones, 0.5 cun proximal to the second point of Shoujie (T 22.10) , along the edge of the 5th metacarpal. Some sources state it is 1 - 1.5 cun proximal to Shaofu (HT 8) , which is where the tip of the little finger touches when a fist is made. To determine where to needle, palpate for the strongest ah shi sensation in this area of the palm.
primary_indications: Primary: Stunted growth, delayed development in children
secondary_indications: Secondary: Peritonitis, pleurisy, appendicitis, oophoritis, acute or chronic enteritis
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.8 cun .

name: Shangjiuli (T 88.26)
location: This point is between the ST and GB channels, 1.5 cun anterior to Zhongjiuli (T 88.25) , which is on the GB channel at the midpoint of the midline of the lateral thigh.
primary_indications: Primary: Arm pain (HT channel) Abdominal distension (KI channel) from deficiency Eye pain, increased eye pressure, dizziness
secondary_indications: Secondary: Back pain, upper back pain, neck pain, vertebral pain Inability to raise arm due to shoulder pain, frozen shoulder, numbness of the arm, weakness of lower limbs Migraine
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun .

name: Shangli (T 1010.09)
location: This point overlaps with Zanzhu (BL 2) , which is superior to the inner canthus, in a depression on the medial end of the eyebrow. Some books state this point is 0.2 cun above Zanzhu (BL 2) .
primary_indications: Primary: All disorders of the eyes: blurry vision, failing vision, twitching of eyelids, glaucoma, supraorbital pain, lacrimation, red eyes, swollen eyes, painful eyes
secondary_indications: Secondary: Headache, dizziness, vertigo
techniques: Needle subcutaneously and inferiorly 0.1 - 0.2 cun .

name: Shangliu (T 55.06)
location: This point is on the KI channel, on the sole of the foot, at the center of the anterior edge of the heel on the plantar surface proximal to Yongquan (KI 1) .
primary_indications: Primary: Brain tumor, brain cancer, headache, swelling of the cerebellum, cranial nerve pain, concussion, head injuries, unconsciousness
secondary_indications: Secondary: Trigeminal neuralgia Stuffy nose, nose bleeding
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.5 cun .

name: Shangqi (T 88.44)*
location: This point is on the BL channel, 1.6 cun lateral to Weizhong (BL 40) , which is in the center of the popliteal fossa.
primary_indications: Primary: Cardiac Disorders: angina pectoris, myocardiac infarction (heart attack), chest pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Enlarged heart, cardiac weakness Headache, upper back pain
techniques: Needle 0.5 cun . This point can also be bled.

name: Shangqu (T 44.16)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.16 Shangqu , is on the lateral aspect of the upper arm, in between the LI and TH channels, 1 cun posterior to the center of the deltoid muscle.
primary_indications: Primary: Sciatica Arm pain, leg pain Hemiplegia
secondary_indications: Secondary: Post-polio syndrome Hypertension
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1.5 cun .

name: Shangquan (T 88.22)
location: This point is on the GB channel, 6.5 cun proximal to the center of the knee joint along the midline of the lateral thigh. It is 2 cun proximal to Zhongquan (T 88.21) .
primary_indications: Primary: Facial paralysis, TMJ, deviation of the eyes, deviation of mouth, facial twitch, facial tic, hemiplegia, thrombosis, post-stroke complications Tinnitus, difficulty hearing
secondary_indications: Secondary: Shoulder pain Dysmenorrhea Skin allergy
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun on the healthy side.

name: Shener (T 99.09)*
location: This is a three-point set on the posterior ear groove. Divide the groove into fourths, and locate these three points at , , and  of the groove. The upper point and lower point are approximately at the same locations as the auricular Lumbosacral Posterior Point and C3-C4 Posterior Point, respectively, in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
primary_indications: Primary: Various emergencies such as heart attack, vertigo or dizziness, chest oppression or tightness
secondary_indications: Secondary: Headache, vomiting, liver failure, weak extremities, anemia, syncope, stroke, high cholesterol, high blood pressure, chest and upper back pain, low back pain, motion sickness
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun at an angle downwards.

name: Shenjian (T 44.19)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.19* Shenjian , is on the shoulder, close to the LI channel, between Jianfeng (T 44.31)* and Yunbai (T 44.11) .[ Jianfeng (T 44.31)* is located 0.5 cun inferior to Jianyu (LI 15) . Yunbai (T 44.11) is located 1 cun anterior and 1 cun superior to the center of the deltoid muscle.]
primary_indications: Primary: Post-polio syndrome Hemiplegia from thrombosis, cerebral hemorrhage, arm numbness and pain, inner thigh numbness and pain, bi zheng (painful obstruction syndrome)
secondary_indications: Secondary: Insomnia
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun or obliquely downward 0.5 - 1 cun .

name: Shi Er Hou (T VT.02)
location: 12 points total These points are arranged in 2 lines of 3 points inferior to the clavicle (6 points on each side). The first line is 1.3 cun inferior to the clavicle, and the second line is 2.8 cun inferior to the clavicle. The 3 points are 1.5 cun apart. 8 of the points are nearby or on Kufang (ST 14) , Wuyi (ST 15) , Shencang (KI 25) , Yuzhong (KI 26) .
primary_indications: Primary: Cholera  "Monkey Sha" which is scarlet fever or the result of severe common cold or flu, cholera Asthma due to arteriosclerosis Food poisoning with abdominal pain but no vomiting Diarrhea
techniques: Pinch the skin while bleeding the points to avoid unnecessary harm.

name: Shiyin (T 88.32)
location: This is a two-point set on the SP channel. The first point is at the center of the medial aspect of the knee joint, and the second point is 2 cun inferior to the first point.
primary_indications: Primary: Hoarseness of the voice, loss of voice
secondary_indications: Secondary: Swollen throat, tonsillitis, thyroiditis, parathyroiditis
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun , or thread the needles towards the KI channel.

name: Shoujie (T 22.10)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.10 Shoujie , is a two-point set on the palmar aspect of the hand, along the HT channel between the 4th and 5th metacarpal bones. The first point overlaps with Shaofu (HT 8) , which is where the tip of the little finger touches the palm when a fist is made. In general, this will be on the distal transverse palmar crease. The second point is 0.5 cun proximal to the first point. There are some sources that state this is an individual point (overlapping Shaofu (HT 8) ), while others state that it is a three-point set, with the third point being 0.5 cun proximal to the second one.
primary_indications: Primary: Fainting needle, adverse reaction to acupuncture such as numbness, disorientation of qi flow Back pain, sciatic pain Food poisoning, drug poisoning, medication overdose
secondary_indications: Secondary: Severe pain, cancer-related pain (especially Lung cancer and nasopharyngeal cancer), used as an anesthesia point for dental work and surgeries, post-surgical scar pain, fibromyalgia Acute enteritis, gallstones, cholecystitis Genital itching, uterine prolapse TMJ disorder
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.2 - 0.8 cun. This point can also be bled for a more immediate effect. Needle contralateral to the affected side.

name: Shoujingdian (T 22.19)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.19 Shoujingdian , is on the TH channel, on the dorsal aspect of the hand in between the 3rd and 4th metacarpal bones, 0.5 cun proximal to the MCP joint.
primary_indications: Primary: Neck pain of all types, especially shaoyang , taiyang and Du (governing) channel neck pains.
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side.

name: Shouqianjin (T 33.09)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.09 Shouqianjin , is between the TH and SI channels, 8 cun proximal to the wrist, 0.5 cun ulnar to the TH channel.
primary_indications: Primary: All acute pain Sciatica, upper back pain, back pain, calf pain, calf distension, calf cramp, numbness of hands and feet, leg pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Headache, abdominal pain Drug or food poisoning Early stage of carbuncles, furuncles, boils, tumor, cancer
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 1.5 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side.

name: Shouwujin (T 33.08)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.08 Shouwujin , is between the TH and SI channels, 6.5 cun proximal to the wrist, 0.5 cun ulnar to the TH channel.
primary_indications: Primary: All acute pain Sciatica, upper back pain, back pain, calf pain, calf distension, calf cramp, numbness of hands and feet, leg pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Headache, abdominal pain Drug or food poisoning Early stage of carbuncles, furuncles, boils, tumor, cancer
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 1.5 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side.

name: Shouying (T 44.03)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.03 Shouying , is on the TH channel, 4.5 cun proximal to the olecranon along the posterior edge of the humerus. It is 2 cun proximal to Houzhui (T 44.02) .
primary_indications: Primary: Subluxation or dislocation of the spine, spine pain, back pain Nephritis Bronchitis
secondary_indications: Secondary: Hypertension Thirst, dry mouth, nighttime cough in the elderly Shoulder pain, frozen shoulder, shoulder numbness
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun along the side of the bone or touching the bone.

name: Shuang Feng (T DT.05)
location: 14 points total These points are 1.5 cun lateral to the spinous process of T2 to T8 (7 points on each side). 12 of the 14 points overlap with Fengmen (BL 12) , Feishu (BL 13) , Jueyinshu (BL 14) , Xinshu (BL 15) , Dushu (BL 16) , Geshu (BL 17) .
primary_indications: Primary: Hand pain, hand numbness Foot pain, foot numbness Arteriosclerosis on the arm or leg

name: Shuang He (T DT.16)
location: 12 points total These points are 3 cun lateral to the spine at the level ofL2 to S2 (6 points on each side). 4 of the 12 points overlap with Zhishi (BL 52) and Baohuang (BL 53) .
primary_indications: Primary: Forearm pain, scapular pain, back pain

name: Shuangling (T 11.28)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.28* Shuangling , is a two-point set on the palmar aspect of the middle finger, along the radial and ulnar margins of the PIP joint. Each point is 0.25 cun ulnar and radial to the center of the PIP joint (lines B and D).
primary_indications: Primary: Cancer: lung cancer, liver cancer, bone cancer, throat cancer, leukemia Cardiovascular disorders: cardiomegaly, arrhythmia, endocarditis, angina
secondary_indications: Secondary: Nephritis with edema Oral ulcers, indigestion in children, gastritis, whopping cough, gan ji (infantile malnutrition) Liver cirrhosis Vitiligo
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side. If the condition is in the center, needle the side that is more painful upon palpation. This point can also be bled, especially in cases of pediatric disease. It is most effective when dark blood or yellowish liquid is squeezed out.

name: Shuanglonger (T 77.30)*
location: This point is on the ST channel, 2.1 cun below Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament when the knee is flexed.
primary_indications: Primary: All breast disorders: breast cancer, tumor, fibrocystic breast, breast pain, nipple pain, nipple infection
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 0.8 cun .

name: Shuanglongyi (T 77.29)*
location: This point is on the ST channel, 1.5 cun below Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament when the knee is flexed.
primary_indications: Primary: All breast disorders: breast cancer, tumor, fibrocystic breast, breast pain, nipple pain, nipple infection
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 0.8 cun .

name: Shui Er (T 99.06)
location: This point is located at the lower end of the antihelix, in the depression between the inferior border of the antihelix and the scapha. It is approximately at the same location as the auricular Clavicle Point in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine. Some sources indicate this point to be more medial, on the antitragus, at the lower end of the antihelix.
primary_indications: Primary: Kidney deficiency with soreness and weakness of the back, low back pain, myopia, blurry vision, dry mouth
secondary_indications: Secondary: Abdominal distension
techniques: Use thinnest gauge possible and needle 0.1 to 0.2 cun .

name: Shuifu (T DT.14)
location: 2 points total These two points are 1.5 cun lateral to the spinous process of L2, one on each side, overlapping Shenshu (BL 23) .
primary_indications: Primary: Back pain, back soreness, lumbar pain, spine pain, inability to bend the back, acute back sprain Kidney deficiency, acute nephritis, impotence, premature ejaculation, kidney stone, urinary stone, urinary retention, blurry vision
secondary_indications: Secondary: Irregular menstruation Constipation, enteritis Thirst, insomnia Headache Diabetes Non-descent of fetus
techniques: Needle 0.8 - 1 cun

name: Shuijin (T 1010.20)
location: This point is on the face, close to the ST channel, about 1 cun inferior and 0.5 cun medial to the corner of the mouth, or 0.5 cun obliquely medial to Shuitong (T 1010.19) .
primary_indications: Primary: Rheumatism Kidney deficiency causing back pain, fatigue, dizziness, blurry vision, asthma, cough Hiccup, abdominal distension, bloating, vomiting
secondary_indications: Secondary: Acute back sprain, chest and rib pain
techniques: Needle obliquely and away from the midline, 0.1 - 0.5 cun . It is not necessary to be exact on the point location. Look for an area near this point that is dark or purplish in color to needle for best results.

name: Shuijing (T 66.13)
location: This point is on the KI channel, 2 cun below the tip of the medial malleolus. Some sources state that this point overlaps with Zhaohai (KI 6) , which is in the depression below the tip of the medial malleolus.
primary_indications: Primary: Gynecological disorders: uterine tumors, lower abdominal distension, PID, ovarian cysts, infertility, polycystic ovaries, endometriosis
techniques: Perpendicular insertion 0.5 - 1 cun along the bone. Visible veins near this point can be bled, especially for chronic gynecological disorders.

name: Shuiqu (T 66.09)
location: This point overlaps with Zulinqi (GB 41) , which is between the 4th and 5th metatarsal bones, 1.5 cun proximal to the web margin, in the depression lateral to the tendon of the m. extensor digiti minimi of the foot.
primary_indications: Primary: Back pain Edema, fluid retention, swelling of the limbs from poor kidney function Tinnitus, itchy eyes
secondary_indications: Secondary: Muscle atrophy, numbness Generalized joint pain, neck pain, shoulder pain, wrist pain or weakness, nerve pain, sciatica on the GB channel, xing bi (mobile painful obstruction), dai (girdle) channel waist pain Weight loss Abdominal distension
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun .

name: Shuitong (T 1010.19)
location: This point is on the face, close to the ST channel, 0.4 cun inferior to the corner of the mouth.
primary_indications: Primary: Rheumatism Kidney deficiency causing low back pain, fatigue, dizziness, blurry vision, asthma
secondary_indications: Secondary: Acute back sprain, chest pain, rib pain when breathing
techniques: Needle obliquely and away from the midline, 0.1 - 0.5 cun . It is not necessary to be exact on the point location. Look for an area near this point that is dark or purplish in color to needle for best results.

name: Shuixian (T 66.15)
location: This point is on the KI channel, 2 cun directly inferior or distal to Taixi (KI 3) , which is posterior to the medial malleolus, in the depression between the tip of the medial malleolus and the tendo calcaneus.
primary_indications: Primary: Nephritis, back pain due to Kidney deficiency, edema of the limbs, proteinuria
secondary_indications: Secondary: Cataracts Pre-eclampsia, postpartum fever
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun . Needle on or closer to the anterior border of the Achilles tendon for better effect. Penetrate the needle through to Kunlun (BL 60) for best effect.

name: Shuixiang (T 66.14)
location: This point overlaps with Taixi (KI 3) , which is posterior to the medial malleolus, in the depression between the tip of the medial malleolus and the tendo calcaneus.
primary_indications: Primary: Nephritis, back pain due to Kidney deficiency, edema of the lower limbs, proteinuria
secondary_indications: Secondary: Pre-eclampsia, postpartum fever Cataract, blurry vision
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun . Needle on or closer to the anterior border of the Achilles tendon for better effect. Penetrate the needle through to Kunlun (BL 60) for best effect.

name: Shuiyu (T 44.17)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.17 Shuiyu , overlaps with Naoshu (SI 10) . Withthe arm adducted, follow the posterior axillary crease superiorly to a depression just below the scapular spine. Some sources state this point is 0.5 cun above Jianzhen (SI 9) , which liesposterior and inferior to the shoulder joint, and 1 cun above the posterior end of the axillary fossa.
primary_indications: Primary: Kidney stones, nephritis, proteinuria, low back pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Dorsal wrist pain, carpal tunnel syndrome, arm pain, leg muscle pain General weakness Urticaria, excessive perspiration, nail fungus
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun . Use a lancet to prick yellow fluids from this point to treat kidney diseases. When treating arm, wrist or hand pain, bleed the same side for dark blood.

name: Shuizhong (T DT.13)
location: 2 points total These two points are 1.5 cun lateral to the spinous process of L1, one on each side, overlapping Sanjiaoshu (BL 22) .
primary_indications: Primary: Kidney deficiency, nephritis Irregular menstruation Back pain, lumbar pain, spine pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Constipation Thirst
techniques: Needle 0.8 - 1 cun

name: Sifuer (T 1010.10)
location: This point overlaps with Yuyao , which is 0.2 cun above the center of the eyebrow.
primary_indications: Primary: All eye disorders, blurry vision, red eyes, eye pain, floaters Frontal headache, dizziness Abdominal distension, bloating
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun subcutaneously and inferiorly. This point can also be bled. To treat acute headaches, epilepsy, and mania, it is best to bleed this point.

name: Sifuyi (T 1010.11)
location: This point overlaps with Sizhukong (TH 23) , which is 0.2 cun above the lateral end of the eyebrow.
primary_indications: Primary: All eye disorders, blurry vision, red eyes, eye pain, floaters Frontal headache, dizziness Abdominal distension, bloating
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun subcutaneously and inferiorly. This point can also be bled. To treat acute headaches, epilepsy, and mania, it is best to bleed this point.

name: Sihuafu (T 77.10)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 10 cun distal to Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament on the knee.
primary_indications: Primary: Respiratory disorders: asthma, fluid retention in the lung, tuberculosis, emphysema, pleuritis, pneumonia, lung tumor, lung cancer Cardiovascular disorders: coronary heart disease, arteriosclerosis, myocardial infarct, endocarditis, myocarditis, angina pectoris, chest distension, chest pain, shortness of breath, heart failure, cardiomegaly, palpitation, arrhythmia Gastrointestinal disorders: acute enteritis, stomach pain, diarrhea
secondary_indications: Secondary: Frozen shoulder, index finger pain, elbow pain, cubital fossa pain, bone swelling Eye pain, pain of the eyeball, conjunctivitis, cataracts
techniques: Needle 2 - 3 cun for asthma and eye pain. Bilateral needling is recommended for treating lung disorders, pain of the elbow, scapula and fingers. This point can also be bled. Bleed veins around this point with a three-edged needle for best therapeutic effect to treat arteriosclerosis, acute stomach pain, enteritis, chest congestion, and pleuritis.

name: Sihuali (T 77.13)
location: This point is on the SP channel, 1.2 cun medial to Sihuazhong (T 77.09) or 7.5 cun distal to Dubi (ST 35) and 1.2 cun medial, on the inner border of the tibia.
primary_indications: Primary: Cardiovascular disorders: coronary heart disease, arteriosclerosis, myocardial infarct, endocarditis, myocarditis, angina pectoris, chest distension, chest pain, shortness of breath, heart failure, cardiomegaly, palpitation, arrhythmia Gastrointestinal disorders: enteritis, gastritis, vomiting
secondary_indications: Secondary: Degenerative arthritis of the knees
techniques: Needle 1.5 - 2 cun . This point can also be bled. Bleeding the veins near the Dao Ma points can treat all cardiovascular, digestive, hepatic, and respiratory disorders. Also, it is beneficial for headaches, sciatica, and pleuritis.

name: Sihuashang (T 77.08)
location: This point overlaps with Zusanli (ST 36) , which is 3 cun below the depression lateral to the patella ligament.
primary_indications: Primary: Gastrointestinal disorders: duodenal ulcers, stomach ulcers Cardiovascular disorders: coronary heart disease, arteriosclerosis, myocardial infarct, endocarditis, myocarditis, angina pectoris, chest distension, chest pain, shortness of breath, heart failure, cardiomegaly, palpitation, arrhythmia Toothache
secondary_indications: Secondary: Canker sores Vomiting, huo luan (sudden turmoil disorder) Asthma
techniques: Needle 2 cun for respiratory conditions, 3 cun for cardiovascular conditions. Needle along the edge of the tibia for maximum effect. This point can also be bled. Bleeding the dark veins in this area can also be effective for chronic history of any of the conditions listed above.

name: Sihuawai (T 77.14)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 7.5 cun distal and 1.5 cun lateral to Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament on the knee, close to Tiaokou (ST 38) and Fenglong (ST 40) .
primary_indications: Primary: Acute enteritis, chronic enteritis Upper back pain Mastitis
secondary_indications: Secondary: Abdominal distention, appendix pain Toothache, migraines, ear pain, intercostal neuralgia, shoulder pain, arm pain, lateral epicondylitis, sciatica, instep pain, sole pain Facial paralysis Eyeball disorders Hypertension, headache, high cholesterol leading to dizziness, myocardial infarct Pneumonia Neurasthenia
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun . Shoulder pain and migraines, needle the side opposite to the affected area. Asthma and cold feet, needle bilaterally. This point can also be bled. Enteritis and the other conditions listed above (excluding the conditions under the needling techniques list directly above), bleed dark veins near this point.

name: Sihuaxia (T 77.11)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 12.5 cun distal to Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament on the knee. This point is 2.5 cun below Sihuafu (T 77.10) .
primary_indications: Primary: Gastrointestinal disorders: acute enteritis, stomach pain, bloating
secondary_indications: Secondary: Edema Teeth grinding at night Facial paralysis Chest and abdominal fullness Knee and heel bone spurs
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun . Needling along the tibia is especially helpful when treating knee and heel bone spurs. This point can also be bled.

name: Sihuazhong (T 77.09)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 7.5 cun distal to Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament on the knee.
primary_indications: Primary: Respiratory disorders: pneumonia, asthma, pleural effusion, pleuritis, tuberculosis, emphysema, lung tumor, lung cancer Cardiovascular disorders: coronary heart disease, arteriosclerosis, myocardial infarct, endocarditis, myocarditis, angina pectoris, chest distension, chest pain, shortness of breath, heart failure, cardiomegaly, palpitation, arrhythmia Gastrointestinal disorders: acute enteritis, stomach pain, gastritis
secondary_indications: Secondary: Disorders of the eyes: soreness and pain of the eyeball, conjunctivitis, cataracts Frozen shoulder, index finger pain, elbow pain, cubital fossa pain, bone swelling
techniques: Needle 1.5 - 2 cun for asthma and eye problems, 3 cun for heart disease. Needling close to or along the tibia can yield the best therapeutic effect. Bilateral needling is recommended for treating lung disorders, pain of the elbow, scapula, and fingers. This point can also be bled, especially when treating gastrointestinal disorders, cardiovascular disorders, chest stuffiness and pleurisy. Veins around this point can be bled with a three-edged needle to treat arteriosclerosis, acute stomach pain, enteritis, and chest congestion.

name: Simashang (T 88.18)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 3 cun anterior and 2 cun proxmial to the place touched by the middle fingertip when one is standing with the hands at the sides (at Fengshi (GB 31) ). It is 2 cun superior to Simazhong (T 88.17) .
primary_indications: Primary: Respiratory disorders Lung deficiency, chest pain, pleurisy, allergy, sinusitis, rhinitis, stuffy nose, pulmonary tuberculosis, asthma, pneumonia, common cold Shaoyang disorders Costochondritis, rib pain, intercostal pain, hypochondriac pain, conjunctivitis, red eyes, protruding eyes in hyperthyroidism, tinnitus, ankle sprain, hemangioma, goiter Skin disorders Eczema, psoriasis, neurodermatitis, allergic dermatitis, acne, blackheads, freckles Breast disorders Fibrocystic breast, mastitis, breast pain Pain Back and sciatic pain due to LU channel deficiency ( taiyin - taiyang relationship), wrist pain, upper back pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Hemiplegia, facial paralysis Bone spurs Inflammation of the diaphragm Over-eating
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.8 - 2.5 cun . Needle bilaterally, except when treating pain. For pain, needle contralateral to the affected side.

name: Simaxia (T 88.19)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 3 cun anterior and 2 cun distal to the place touched by the middle fingertip when one is standing with the hands at the sides (at Fengshi (GB 31) ). It is 2 cun inferior to Simazhong (T 88.17) .
primary_indications: Primary: Respiratory disorders Lung deficiency, chest pain, pleurisy, allergy, sinusitis, rhinitis, stuffy nose, pulmonary tuberculosis, asthma, pneumonia, common cold Shaoyang disorders Costochondritis, rib pain, intercostal pain, conjunctivitis, red eyes, protruding eyes in hyperthyroidism, tinnitus, ankle sprain, hemangioma, goiter Skin disorders Eczema, psoriasis, neurodermatitis, allergic dermatitis, acne, blackheads, freckles Breast disorders Fibrocystic breast, mastitis, breast pain Pain Back and sciatic pain due to LU channel deficiency ( taiyin - taiyang relationship), wrist pain, upper back pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Hemiplegia, facial paralysis Bone spurs Inflammation of the diaphragm Over-eating
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.8 - 2.5 cun . Needle bilaterally, except when treating pain. For pain, needle contralateral to the affected side.

name: Simazhong (T 88.17)
location: This point is on the ST channel, 3 cun anterior to the place touched by the middle fingertip when one is standing with the hands at the sides (at Fengshi (GB 31) ), near Futu (ST 32) .
primary_indications: Primary: Respiratory disorders Lung deficiency, chest pain, pleurisy, allergy, sinusitis, rhinitis, stuffy nose, pulmonary tuberculosis, asthma, pneumonia, common cold Shaoyang disorders Costochondritis, rib pain, intercostal pain, conjunctivitis, red eyes, protruding eyes in hyperthyroidism, tinnitus, ankle sprain, hemangioma, goiter Skin disorders Eczema, psoriasis, neurodermatitis, allergic dermatitis, acne, blackheads, freckles Breast disorders Fibrocystic breast, mastitis, breast pain Pain Back and sciatic pain due to LU channel deficiency ( taiyin - taiyang relationship), wrist pain, upper back pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Hemiplegia, facial paralysis Bone spurs Inflammation of the diaphragm Over-eating
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.8 - 2.5 cun . Needle bilaterally, except when treating pain. For pain, needle contralateral to the affected side.

name: Sizhi (T 77.20)
location: This point is on the SP channel, 4 cun proximal to the tip of the medial malleolus.
primary_indications: Primary: Arm pain, hand pain, foot pain Neck pain Diabetes
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1.2 cun .

name: Tianer (T 99.10)*
location: This point is on the posterior ear groove. It is 0.2 cun lateral to the upper point of Shener (T 99.09)*.
primary_indications: Primary: Various poisoning (food, medication, drugs), skin allergies
secondary_indications: Secondary: Dizziness, vomiting, motion sickness
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.2 cun .

name: Tianhuang (T 77.17)
location: This point overlaps with Yinlingquan (SP 9) , which is located on the medial aspect of the lower leg, in the depression posterior and inferior to the medial condyle of the tibia.
primary_indications: Primary: Heartburn, acid reflux, diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, diabetes Nephritis, proteinuria, cystitis, frequent urination
secondary_indications: Secondary: Belching, mei he qi (plum-pit qi) Heart disease with or without high blood pressure, dizziness, headache, insomnia Kidney deficiency disorders: impotence, premature ejaculation, dysmenorrhea, pain associated with the bones (especially shoulder pain, neck and upper back pain in the T1, T2 area) Urinary and kidney disorders, including lin zheng (dysuria syndrome), xue lin (bloody dysuria), gao lin (cloudy dysuria), ascites, edema Radiating arm pain and neck tightness/pain, SCM tightness and pain, tightness along the BL channel in the neck and upper back
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 2.5 cun along the edge of the bone. This point can also be bled.

name: Tianhuang (T 88.13)
location: This point is on the LR channel, 3 cun proximal to Minghuang (T 88.12) , which is at the center of the midline of the medial thigh.
primary_indications: Primary: Any hepatic and gallbladder disorders, especially hepatitis, liver cirrhosis, jaundice, liver cancer Impaired liver function leading to fatigue and exhaustion, vertigo, eye pain, blurry vision, liver spots, hypochondriac pain, gallstones, indigestion, bloating from insufficient bile secretion, Mnire's disease Leukemia, elevated white blood cell count
secondary_indications: Secondary: Post-stroke complications, hemiplegia Multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, chorea Liver qi stagnation leading to nervousness, anxiety, insomnia Low back soreness, bone swelling, spine periostitis, xing bi (mobile painful obstruction), lateral arm pain from elbow to wrist, bone spur Leukorrhea, irregular menstruation Bleeding gums, anemia Urinary retention, urinary incontinence High blood pressure, low blood pressure Hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia Epilepsy
techniques: Needle 1 - 3 cun towards the femur. Superficial depth addresses KI, middle depth addresses LR, and deep level needling addresses HT.

name: Tianhuangfu [shenguan] (T 77.18)
location: This point is on the SP channel, 1.5 cun inferior to Yinlingquan (SP 9) , which is in the depression of the lower border of the medial condyle of the tibia on the medial aspect of the lower leg.
primary_indications: Primary: Back pain due to Kidney deficiency, sciatica, headache, upper back pain, interscapular pain, frequent urination at night Acid reflux, nausea Deviation of the eye, astigmatism, supraorbital pain, sinus bone pain Dizziness Neurosis, epilepsy
secondary_indications: Secondary: Frozen shoulder, limited range of motion, finger numbness High uric acid levels Heartburn, mei he qi (plum-pit qi), epigastric pain, chest pain Disorders of the eyes: floaters, near-sightedness, tearing of the eyes Insomnia, hysteria Diseases of the blood, anemia, diabetes
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 2 cun .

name: Tianshi (T 33.15)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.15 Tianshi , is 10 cun proximal to the wrist crease on the LU or PC channel, 3 cun proximal to Dishi (T 33.14) .
primary_indications: Primary: Asthma Palpitations, tachycardia
secondary_indications: Secondary: Early stages of common cold, rhinitis, bronchitis Arrhythmia, cardiac insufficiency, chest fullness and distension Headache, upper body disorders, back pain, arm pain
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 1 - 1.5 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected area. If the condition is in the center, needle bilaterally. Use shallow insertion for respiratory issues or conditions that are recent in onset. Use deep insertion for cardiac disorders or chronic, long-term conditions. Since this point is on or in between the PC or LU channel, select the PC channel when treating cardiovascular problems and use the LU channel when treating respiratory disorders.

name: Tianweixue (T 22.27)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.27* Tianweixue , in an ashi point is locatedbetween Lieque (LU 7) and Yangxi (LI 5) .
primary_indications: Primary: Smoking and substance abuse urges to overcome addiction
techniques: Needle, moxa, or massage

name: Tianzong (T 44.10)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.10 Tianzong , is on the LI channel, 9 cun proximal to the cubital crease, in the depression between the lateral border of the humerus and the m. biceps brachii, or 3 cun proximal to Dizong (T 44.09) . Some sources indicate this point is on the LU channel.
primary_indications: Primary: Leukorrhea, vaginitis, genital itching, red or white vaginal discharge
secondary_indications: Secondary: Urogenital pain, vaginal pain, lower abdominal pain Body odor, underarm odor Leg pain (medial), calf distension, calf swelling, calf pain Post-polio syndrome, infantile paralysis Diabetes mellitus Headache from cardiac insufficiency
techniques: Needle 1 - 1.5 cun .

name: Tongbei (T 88.11)
location: This point is on the SP channel, 4 cun proximal to the superior medial corner of the patella. It is 2 cun proximal to Xuehai (SP 10) .
primary_indications: Primary: Kidney disorders: Nephritis, edema, lin zheng (dysuria syndrome) with pronounced urine odor, diabetes, chronic nephritis, proteinuria, pyelonephritis, cystitis Kidney deficiency: Back pain, bi zheng (painful obstruction syndrome) Impotence, premature ejaculation, dizziness Red or white vaginal discharge, inflammation of the uterus, lower abdominal pain, threatened miscarriage
secondary_indications: Secondary: Sore throat, dry throat, throat tumor Jaundice Diabetes
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1 cun

name: Tongguan (T 88.01)
location: This point is on the anterior midline of the thigh, 5 cun above the upper margin of the patella, close to Futu (ST 32) .
primary_indications: Primary: All heart diseases: Coronary heart disorder, congestive heart failure, arrhythmia, rheumatic heart disease, palpitations, fainting sensation and lightheadedness, vertigo, acute pericarditis, pericardium disorders, cerebral ischemia, poor blood circulation, chest pain Nausea and vomiting Headache, migraine
secondary_indications: Secondary: Anemia
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 2 cun .

name: Tongshan (T 88.02)
location: This point is on the anterior midline of the thigh, 7 cun above the upper margin of the patella, or 2 cun proximal to Tongguan (T 88.01) .
primary_indications: Primary: All heart diseases: Coronary heart disorder, congestive heart failure, arrhythmia, rheumatic heart disease, palpitations, fainting sensation and lightheadedness, vertigo, acute pericarditis, pericardium disorders, cerebral ischemia, poor blood circulation, chest pain, limb pain Nausea and vomiting
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 2 cun .

name: Tongshen (T 88.09)
location: This point is on the SP channel, in the depression at the superior medial corner of the patella.
primary_indications: Primary: Kidney disorders: Nephritis, edema, lin zheng (dysuria syndrome) with pronounced urine odor, diabetes, chronic nephritis, proteinuria, pyelonephritis, cystitis Kidney deficiency: Back pain, bi zheng (painful obstruction syndrome) Impotence, premature ejaculation, dizziness Red or white vaginal discharge, inflammation of the uterus, lower abdominal pain, threatened miscarriage
secondary_indications: Secondary: Sore throat, dry throat, throat tumor Jaundice Diabetes
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1 cun .

name: Tongtian (T 88.03)
location: This point is on the anterior midline of the thigh, 9 cun above the upper margin of the patella, 4 cun proximal to Tongguan (T 88.01) .
primary_indications: Primary: All heart diseases: Coronary heart disorder, congestive heart failure, arrhythmia, rheumatic heart disease, palpitations, fainting sensation and lightheadedness, vertigo, acute pericarditis, pericardium disorders, cerebral ischemia, poor blood circulation, chest pain, limb pain Nausea and vomiting
secondary_indications: Secondary: Knee pain, back pain, finger pain Leg weakness, lower body wei zheng (atrophy syndrome) or paralysis, leg qi Lower body eczema
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1 cun . Needle more than 1.2 cun deep to treat lower body wei zheng (atrophy syndrome) or paralysis, eczema, back pain, and leg qi .

name: Tongwei (T 88.10)
location: This point overlaps with Xuehai (SP 10) , which is 2 cun proximal to the superior medial corner of the patella.
primary_indications: Primary: Kidney disorders: Nephritis, edema, impotence, lin zheng (dysuria syndrome) with pronounced urine odor, diabetes, chronic nephritis, proteinuria, pyelonephritis, cystitis Kidney deficiency: Back pain, bi zheng (painful obstruction syndrome) Impotence, premature ejaculation, dizziness Red or white vaginal discharge, inflammation of the uterus, lower abdominal pain, threatened miscarriage
secondary_indications: Secondary: Sore throat, dry throat, throat tumor Jaundice Diabetes Upper back pain near Gaohuangshu (BL 43)
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1 cun .

name: Tu Er (T 99.04)
location: This point is located in between the cymba concha and cavum concha, at the end of the helix crus where it disappears into the concha. It is approximately at the same location as the auricular Splenomegaly Area in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
primary_indications: Primary: Neurasthenia, elevated red blood cell, fever, diabetes
techniques: Use thinnest gauge possible and needle 0.1 to 0.2 cun .

name: Tuling (T 88.46)*
location: This point is on the SP channel, 1 cun distal to Xuehai (SP 10) , which is 2 cun proximal to the medial superior corner of the patella on the SP channel.
primary_indications: Primary: White blood cell and red blood cell disorders: Leukemia, anemia caused by faulty red blood cell production, elevated or low levels of white blood cell, acute blood disorders
techniques: Needle 1 - 1.5 cun .

name: Tung's Wantong (T 66.16)*
location: This is a 2 point set. The first point is inferior to the tip of the lateral malleoluson the lower border of the calcaneus. The second point is 2 cun distal to the first one.
primary_indications: Primary: Wrist pain
techniques: Needle 1 cun .

name: Tushui (T 22.11)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.11 Tushui , is a three-point set on the LU channel, on the palmar aspect of the thumb, evenly distributed along the radial margin of the metacarpal bone (line A). The center point overlaps with Yuji (LU 10) . The second and third points are 0.5 cun distal and 0.5 cun proximal to the center point.
primary_indications: Primary: Gastritis, gastric ulcer, chronic stomach disorders, heartburn, stomach pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Cough, asthma, tonsillitis Sciatica, swelling of the bones, medial leg pain, periostitis
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1 cun . For knee pain, needle along the edge of the bone.

name: Waier (T 99.13)*
location: On the posterior of the ear, this point is 0.3 cun superior and 0.2 cun lateral to Jiner (T 99.05). It is approximately at the same location as the auricular Tennis Elbow Point in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
primary_indications: Primary: Arrhythmia, palpitation, headache, high diastolic pressure, dizziness, blurry vision Emergency point for stroke and unconsciousness
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.2 cun .

name: Waijian (T 11.04)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.04 Waijian , is located on the palmar aspect of the index finger, along the radial margin of the middle phalangeal bone (line B). Divide the middle phalanx into thirds, and locate this point at the junction of the proximal 1/3 and middle 1/3 of this distance.
primary_indications: Primary: Hernia
secondary_indications: Secondary: Inguinal hernia, femoral hernia Abdominal distension, bloating, stomachache Urinary tract infection, cystitis Toothache
techniques: Needle perpendicularly, adjacent to the edge of the bone, 0.1 - 0.2 cun towards the dorsal aspect of the hand. Needle contralateral to the affected side. Bleeding is also effective for hernia if there are nearby veins or dark spots. The therapeutic effect is most apparent when yellow fluids can be squeezed out when bleeding this point.

name: Waisanguan (T 77.27)
location: This is a three-point set on the GB channel. Divide the distance between the lateral malleolus and the head of the fibula into fourths, and locate these points at , , and  along this line.
primary_indications: Primary: Furuncles, acne, rosacea, tonsillitis, laryngitis, mumps, toxic masses, carbuncles, goiter, abscesses, fibrocystic breast, cystic acne Throat cancer, lung cancer Tumors, benign or malignant cancer in the abdomen or uterus Pain or weakness in the shoulder and arm, frozen shoulder, tennis elbow
secondary_indications: Secondary: Middle ear infection
techniques: Needle 1 - 1.5 cun . For tumors, cancer, tonsillitis and mumps, needle bilaterally. These points can also be bled. It is best if dark blood is removed.

name: Wanshuner (T 22.09)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.09 Wanshuner , is on the ulnar margin of the hand at the junction of the red and white skin, 1.5 cun distal to the wrist joint, 1 cun proximal to Wanshunyi (T 22.08) .
primary_indications: Primary: Sciatica, bone spur Kidney disease: nephritis, edema, cystitis Kidney deficiency with exhaustion, blurry vision, eye pain, deafness, tinnitus, swelling of the bones in the extremities, back pain, back soreness, insomnia, osteoarthritis, popliteal fossa pain Acute neck sprain, fallen pillow syndrome, upper back pain in between the scapulae
secondary_indications: Secondary: Nose bleeding, toothache, facial paralysis, headache
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 1 - 1.5 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side or bilaterally.

name: Wanshunyi (T 22.08)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.08 Wanshunyi , is on the ulnar margin of the hand at the junction of the red and white skin, 2.5 cun distal to the wrist joint crease, or 0.5 cun proximal to Houxi (SI 3) , which is proximal to the 5th MCP joint.
primary_indications: Primary: Kidney deficiency with back pain, back weakness, bone spurs of the neck, sciatica, osteoarthritis Nephritis, pyelonephritis, edema, cystitis
secondary_indications: Secondary: Kidney deficiency with exhaustion, blurry vision, tinnitus, deafness, headache, popliteal fossa pain
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1.5 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side.

name: Wei Mao Qi (T VT.04)
location: 7 points total Point 1 is just inferior to the tip of the xiphoid process and overlaps Zhongting (CV 16) . Point 2 is 1 cun below Point 1. Point 3 is 2 cun below Point 1. Points 4 and 5 are 1.5 cun lateral to Point 2, one on each side. Points 6 and 7 are 1.5 cun lateral to Point 3, one on each side.
primary_indications: Primary: All stomach disorders, gastric bleeding, duodenal ulcer, cholera Palpitation  "Goat's Hair Sha " with dizziness, vomiting, fever, chest congestion, back pain. This condition usually occurs in the summer when one is over-exhausted. It is called "goat's hair sha " because during the recovery stage of this condition, the skin produces something that resembles goat's hair. The removal of this "goat's hair" substance is necessary for complete recovery of this condition.
techniques: This point can be bled.

name: Wuhu (T 11.27)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.27 Wuhu , is a five-point set evenly distributed along the radial aspect of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, at the border between the palmar and dorsal aspects of the thumb between the red and the white skin (line A). The points are numbered so that the most distal is the 1st point and the most proximal is the 5th point. Each point is 2 fen from the next point.
primary_indications: Primary: Bone disorders: arthritis, bone spurs, rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, painful bones, osteoporosis, gout, toe pain, knee pain, ankle pain, heel pain, hand pain, finger pain Pain disorders: fibromyalgia, general bodyache, pain as a side effect of medication use
secondary_indications: Secondary: Pneumonia, tonsillitis, lymphadenitis, bronchitis Vertex headache Hepatomegaly, liver cirrhosis
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun for upper body disorders, 0.2 - 0.4 cun for lower body disorders. The needle needs to touch the tendon or the bone. Needle contralateral to the affected side. This point also can be bled to release blood or clear/yellowish fluids.

name: Wuling (T DT.04)
location: 40 points total The first 10 points are on the spine, below the spinous process of T2 to T11. 7 of the 10 points overlap with Shenzhu (GV 12) , Shendao (GV 11) , Lingtai (GV 10) , Zhiyang (GV 9) , Jinsuo (GV 8) , Zhongshu (GV 7) , Jizhong (GV 6) . The second set of 16 points is 3 cun lateral to the spinous process of T2 to T9 (8 points on each side). 14 of the 16 points overlap with Fufen (BL 41) , Pohu (BL 42) , Gaohuangshu (BL 43) , Shentang (BL 44) , Yixi (BL 45) , Geguan (BL 46) , Hunmen (BL 47) . The third set of 14 points is 6 cun lateral to the spinous process of T2 to T8 (7 points on each side). 4 of the 14 points overlap with Tianzong (SI 11) and Bingfeng (SI 12) .
primary_indications: Primary: Hypertension, headache, numbness of the arms, hands, fingers and feet, chest pain, chest stuffiness, cardiomegaly Any chronic disorder with blood stagnation
secondary_indications: Secondary: Severe common cold, flu, high fever, chills, headache, vomiting Hemiplegia Cholera (yin or yang type), acute stomach pain Back pain from atherosclerosis
techniques: This point can be bled. Pinch the skin first prior to pricking for blood. It is unnecessary to bleed all 40 points. Choose the points that relate to the correct innervations and bleed accordingly.

name: Xiabai (T 22.07)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.07 Xiabai , is located on the TH channel and overlaps with the extra point Yao Tong Xue , which is between the 4th and 5th metacarpal bones, 1.5 cun proximal to the MCP joints of these two fingers. It is 1 cun posterior to Zhongbai (T 22.06) .
primary_indications: Primary: Pain: low back pain, shaoyang channel sciatica, bone spurs, chest pain, rib pain, leg pain, knee pain, lateral ankle sprain, degenerative arthritis, toothache, tinnitus, migraines
secondary_indications: Secondary: Myopia, astigmatism Renal colic, biliary colic
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.5 cun deep. Needle contralateral to the affected side.

name: Xiachun (T 77.16)
location: This point is 1 cun distal to Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament when the knee is flexed. Some books state this point is 1 cun distal from the mid or lower lateral ridge of the patella.
primary_indications: Primary: Lip pain, lip ulcer, lip swelling, mouth ulcer, tongue stiffness, difficulty speaking Thrush or oral candidiasis in children, yeast infection, vitiligo around the mouth or genitals
secondary_indications: Secondary: Oral herpes, genital herpes
techniques: Bleed to expel dark blood and to purge heat to see immediate results.

name: Xiagao (T 22.22)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.22 Xiagao , is on the palmar aspect of the hand, along the HT channel between the 4th and 5th metacarpal bones, 0.5 cun proximal to Shanggao (T 22.21)* , along the edge of the 5th metacarpal. To determine where to needle, palpate for the strongest ah shi sensation in this area of the palm.
primary_indications: Primary: Promotes growth, delayed development in children
secondary_indications: Secondary: Peritonitis, pleurisy, appendicitis, oophoritis, acute or chronic enteritis
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.8 cun .

name: Xiajiuli (T 88.27)
location: This point is between the GB and BL channels, 1.5 cun posterior to Zhongjiuli (T 88.25) , which is on the GB channel at the midpoint of the midline of the lateral thigh.
primary_indications: Primary: Upper back pain, leg pain, thigh pain
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun .

name: Xiaojian (T 11.02)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.02 Xiaojian , is located on the palmar aspect of the index finger, along the radial margin of the proximal phalangeal bone,  distal from the MCP joint (line B).
primary_indications: Primary: Hernia Acute and chronic enteritis Dyspnea, chronic bronchitis
secondary_indications: Secondary: Yellow phlegm, chest congestion, asthma Heart disease, palpitations, shortness of breath, finger numbness Inguinal hernia, femoral hernia, abdominal distension Conjunctivitis, canthus pain Pediatric asthma, gan ji (infantile malnutrition) TMJ pain Tonsillitis
techniques: Needle perpendicularly, adjacent to the edge of the bone, towards the dorsal aspect of the hand. For HT and LU conditions, needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun . For hernia, SI conditions, and knee pain and all other conditions, needle 0.2 - 0.3 cun . Bleeding is also effective for hernia if there are nearby veins or dark spots. Needle contralateral to the affected side.

name: Xiaojie (T 22.13)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.13 Xiaojie , is on the LU channel, at the junction of the shaft and head of the first metacarpal bone, at the border between the palmar and dorsal aspects of the thumb (line A).
primary_indications: Primary: Ankle sprain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Neck pain, shoulder pain, back pain, sciatica, chest pain, and pain of the wrist and elbow Stomach pain, chronic diarrhea
techniques: Thread the needle 1 - 1.5 cun along the bone towards the wrist, Daling (PC 7) .

name: Xiaqi (T 88.45)*
location: This point is 1.6 cun medial to Weizhong (BL 40) , which is in the center of the popliteal fossa.
primary_indications: Primary: Cardiac Disorders: angina pectoris, myocardiac infarction (heart attack), chest pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Enlarged heart, cardiac weakness Headache, upper back pain
techniques: Needle 0.5 cun . This point can also be bled.

name: Xiaqu (T 44.15)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.15 Xiaqu , is on the SI channel, 8 cun proximal to the elbow, on the same level as Naohui (TH 13) .
primary_indications: Primary: Sciatica, hemiplegia Arm pain, leg pain, knee pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Post-polio syndrome Hypertension
techniques: Needle 0.6 - 1.5 cun .

name: Xiaquan (T 88.20)
location: This point is on the GB channel, 2.5 cun proximal to the center of the knee joint along the midline of the lateral thigh.
primary_indications: Primary: Facial paralysis, deviation of the eyes and mouth, facial twitch, facial tic, hemiplegia, thrombosis, post-stroke complications Tinnitus, difficulty hearing
secondary_indications: Secondary: Shoulder pain Dysmenorrhea Skin allergy
techniques: Needle 1 -2 cun on healthy side.

name: Xiaxin (T 99.18)*
location: This is a two-point set at the center of the cavum conchae. It is approximately at the same location as the auricular Heart Point in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
primary_indications: Primary: Angina, arteriosclerosis
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 cun .

name: Xinchang (T 11.19)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.19 Xinchang , is a two-point set on the palmar aspect of the middle finger, evenly distributed along the ulnar margin of the proximal phalangeal bone (line D). Divide the proximal phalanx into thirds, and locate these two points at 1/3 and 2/3 of the distance between the MCP and PIP joints.
primary_indications: Primary: Heart disease: palpitations, tachycardia, cardiomegaly, rheumatic heart disease, coronary artery disease, arrhythmia, bradycardia, angina pectoris
secondary_indications: Secondary: Lung cancer, tuberculosis
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun along the edge of the bone towards the dorsal aspect of the hand. Needle bilaterally. This point can also be bled.

name: Xingfen (T 99.21)*
location: This point is on the antitragus medial to Shuier (T 99.06). It is approximately at the same location as the auricular Stop Asthma Point in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
primary_indications: Primary: Listlessness, lack of motivation in life, sleepiness, neurasthenia, forgetfulness
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.2 cun .

name: Xinling (T 33.17)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.17* Xinling , is a three-point set on the PC channel, 1.5 cun , 2.5 cun , and 3.5 cun proximal to the wrist crease.
primary_indications: Primary: Cardiovascular disorders: endocarditis, arrhythmia, cardiomegaly, chest oppression, angina
secondary_indications: Secondary: Epigastric pain Dizziness, frontal headache Leg pain, numbness of the hands and feet Acupuncture anesthesia point for neck surgeries
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.5 - 1 cun . In severe cases, the needle can be inserted deeply to penetrate through the skin of the TH channel. Needle obliquely at 45 degrees towards the heart, 0.5 - 1 cun , when treating cardiovascular disorders. Needle obliquely at 30 degrees towards the heart, 0.5 - 1 cun , when treating the chest and head. Needle towards the palm to treat hand and foot disorders.

name: Xinmen (T 33.12)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 33.12 Xinmen , is on the SI channel, 1.5 cun distal to the olecranon.
primary_indications: Primary: All cardiovascular disorders: Palpitations, chest stuffiness, coronary heart disease, arrhythmia Vomiting
secondary_indications: Secondary: Pain in the inguinal area, inner thigh pain, coccyx pain, sciatica, medial knee pain Erysipelas
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun towards the wrist. Needle contralateral to the affected side.

name: Xinxi (T 11.09)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.09 Xinxi , is a two-point set on the dorsal side of the middle finger, ulnar and radial to the midpoint of the middle phalanx, along the margins of the phalangeal bone (lines F and H).
primary_indications: Primary: Knee pain around Ququan (LR 8) Neck pain, scapular pain near Gaohuangshu (BL 43)
secondary_indications: Secondary: Calf soreness, swelling, and pain
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun perpendicularly, adjacent to the edge of the bone, towards the palm.

name: Yanhuang (T 11.23)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.23 Yanhuang , is located on the palmar aspect of the little finger, along the midline of the middle phalanx (line C). Locate this point halfway between the PIP and DIP joints.
primary_indications: Primary: Jaundice with yellow eyes, hepatitis
secondary_indications: Secondary: Dizziness, low blood pressure Headache, TMJ disorder, eye disorders, orbital pain Finger pain
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun perpendicularly.

name: Yizhong (T 77.05)
location: This point is between the GB and ST channels, 3 cun proximal to the lateral malleolus, and 1 cun anterior to the fibula. This point is at the same level of Xuanzhong (GB 39) .
primary_indications: Primary: Hyperthyroidism (caused by heart disease), bulging of the eyes, enlarged thyroid, tonsillitis, hepatic diseases, rib pain, teeth clenching at night, migraine Post-stroke complications, deviation of the eyes and mouth, TMJ, post-concussion symptoms Breast disorders: mastitis, fibrocystic breast disease, breast tumors, breast cancer, breast pain Spleen disorders: splenomegaly, abdominal mass Tumors and cancer: brain, breast, esophageal
secondary_indications: Secondary: Meningitis Severe acne Cold bi zheng (painful obstruction syndrome) caused by excessive sexual activities
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun . Needle the healthy side when treating TMJ or deviation of the eyes and mouth. This point can also be bled.

name: Yuhuo (T 1010.21)
location: This point overlaps with Sibai (ST 2) , which is in the depression of the infraorbital foramen directly below the pupil of the eye.
primary_indications: Primary: Sciatica, knee pain Shoulder pain, arm pain Maxillary pain, cheek pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Wrinkles
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun

name: Yunbai (T 44.11)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.11 Yunbai , is in between the LU and LI channels, 1 cun anterior and 1 cun superior to the center of the deltoid muscle. It is in a natural depression on the anterior edge of the deltoid muscle.
primary_indications: Primary: Pelvic inflammatory disease, vaginitis, lower abdominal pain, leukorrhea, red or white vaginal discharge, genital itching
secondary_indications: Secondary: Infantile paralysis, post-polio syndrome Hemiplegia Asthma
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Zhengben (T 1010.12)
location: This point overlaps with Suliao (GV 25) , which is on the tip of the nose.
primary_indications: Primary: Allergic rhinitis, hypertrophic rhinitis, nasal obstruction Mental disorders: psychosis, delirium, decline of mental function, feeling of being possessed by a ghost Rosacea Hangover
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun . Be careful not to injure the cartilage when needling this point. This point is most effective when bled.

name: Zhenghui (T 1010.01)
location: This point overlaps with Baihui (GV 20) , which is 5 cun directly above the midpoint of the anterior hairline or at the midpoint of the line connecting the apexes of the two ears.
primary_indications: Primary: Post-stroke complications such as speech impairment, hemiplegia Interior or exterior wind-related syndrome: tremors, deviation of eye and mouth, infantile convulsions, Parkinson's disease, cerebral palsy, tics
secondary_indications: Secondary: Fatigue, weakness High fever, redness of the eyes, mania Tailbone pain
techniques: Needle forward, backward, or to the side 0.1 - 0.3 cun This point can also be bled

name: Zhengji (T 44.24)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.24* Zhengji , is a three-point set on the LI channel, 2 cun , 4 cun , and 6 cun proximal to the lateral end of the transverse cubital crease. There are some sources that state this set of 3 points is on the LU channel instead.
primary_indications: Primary: Disorders of the bone: bone spurs, inflammation of the spinal membrane, spine pain, stiffness and inability to bend the spine, degenerative disc disorders, sciatica
secondary_indications: Secondary: Chronic nephritis
techniques: Needle perpendicularly or obliquely towards the shoulder 1 - 1.5 cun . This point specifically targets any spinal disorders. It is most effective when the needle touches the bone.

name: Zhengjin (T 77.01)
location: This point is on the BL channel, 3.5 cun proximal to the bottom of the heel on the Achilles tendon. It is midway between Kunlun (BL 60) and Taixi (KI 3) on the midline of the posterior aspect of the lower leg.
primary_indications: Primary: Neck pain, neck sprain, neck stiffness, back pain, back sprain, back stiffness, spine pain, bone spur on the spine, sciatica Cranial enlargement, hydrocephalus, concussion, brain tumor, tinnitus, occipital headache
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 0.8 cun . Use a thicker gauge needle and pierce through the tendon to touch the bone for optimal effect. For stronger patients, needle in a sitting position. For weak patients, needle in a prone or sideway position. This point can also be bled.

name: Zhengshi (T 77.03)
location: This point is on the Achilles tendon, 5.5 cun proximal to the bottom of the heel or 4 cun proximal to Zhengjin (T 77.01) , which is midway between Kunlun (BL 60) and Taixi (KI 3) on the midline of the posterior aspect of the lower leg.
primary_indications: Primary: Neck and shoulder pain, difficulty turning the neck
secondary_indications: Secondary: Low back pain, sprained back, sciatica Headache, chest, and rib pain Clubfoot
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1.5 cun . Use a thicker gauge needle and pierce through the tendon to touch the bone for optimal effect. For stronger patients, needle in a sitting position. For weak patients, needle in a prone or sideway position.

name: Zhengzong (T 77.02)
location: This point is on the Achilles tendon, 5.5 cun proximal to the bottom of the heel or 2 cun proximal to Zhengjin (T 77.01) , which is midway between Kunlun (BL 60) and Taixi (KI 3) on the midline of the posterior aspect of the lower leg.
primary_indications: Primary: Neck and shoulder pain, difficulty turning the neck
secondary_indications: Secondary: Low back pain, sprained back, sciatica Bone swelling, hydrocephalus Epilepsy
techniques: Needle 0.5 - 1 cun . Use a thicker gauge needle and pierce through the tendon to touch the bone for optimal effect. For stronger patients, needle in a sitting position. For weak patients, needle in a prone or sideway position. This point can also be bled.

name: Zhenjing (T 1010.08)
location: This point is 0.3 cun above Yintang , which is midway between the medial ends of the eyebrows.
primary_indications: Primary: Mental-emotional disorders: insomnia, nightmare, night terror or night crying in children/babies
secondary_indications: Secondary: Tremors, restless leg, infantile convulsion, paralysis Weakness of legs, post-partum dizziness Hypertension, sinusitis, frontal headache, heaviness of the head, nosebleed
techniques: Needle subcutaneously 0.3 - 0.5 cun towards the nose. This point can also be bled when treating acute conditions.

name: Zhihan (T 22.18)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.18 Zhihan , is on the TH channel, on the dorsal aspect of the hand, between the 3rd and 4th metacarpal bones, 1.5 cun proximal to these MCP joints.
primary_indications: Primary: Sweating
techniques: Needle 0.3 - 0.5 cun .

name: Zhisanzhong (T 11.14)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.14 Zhisanzhong , is a three-point set on the dorsal aspect of the ring finger, TH channel, evenly distributed along the ulnar margin of the middle phalangeal bone (line F). Divide the middle phalanx into fourths, and locate these three points at , , and  of the distance between the PIP and DIP joints.
primary_indications: Primary: Facial paralysis
secondary_indications: Secondary: Migraine, headache Muscular atrophy, wei zheng (atrophy syndrome) Mastitis, swollen and painful breast or nipple, abscess in the breast, breast tumor, breast cancer
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.2 cun adjacent to the edge of the bone towards the palm.

name: Zhishen (T 11.15)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.15 Zhishen , is a three-point set on the dorsal aspect of the ring finger, TH channel, evenly distributed along the ulnar margin of the proximal phalangeal bone (line F). Divide the proximal phalanx into fourths, and locate these three points at , , and  of the distance between the MCP and PIP joints.
primary_indications: Primary: Heart organ weakness/failure
secondary_indications: Secondary: Asthma Thirst Back pain, interscapular pain Kidney deficiency
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.2 cun adjacent to edge of the bone towards the palm.

name: Zhisima (T 11.07)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.07 Zhisima , is a three-point set on the dorsal aspect of the index finger, on the ulnar margin of the middle phalangeal bone (line F). Divide the middle phalanx into fourths, and locate these three points at , , and  of the distance between the PIP and DIP joints.
primary_indications: Primary: Skin disorders: Acne, rash, dermatitis, liver spots
secondary_indications: Secondary: Sinusitis, rhinitis Shoulder pain, chest pain, rib pain, pleurisy Tinnitus, ear inflammation and infection, dizziness Stops lactation
techniques: Needle 0.2 - 0.3 cun perpendicularly, adjacent to the edge of the bone, towards the palm.

name: Zhitong (T 44.13)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 44.13 Zhitong , is on the SI channel, 4.5 cun proximal to the elbow.
primary_indications: Primary: Hypertension, arteriosclerosis Dizziness, fatigue, low back soreness
techniques: Needle perpendiculary 0.3 - 1 cun , or obliquely 1 - 1.5 cun .

name: Zhiwu (T 11.26)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.26 Zhiwu , is a three-point set on the dorsal aspect of the thumb, evenly distributed along the midline of the proximal phalanx (line G). Divide the proximal phalanx into fourths, and locate these three points at , , and  the distance between the MCP and IP joints.
primary_indications: Primary: Malignant tumor, cancer Chronic, non-healing of wounds or abscess, diabetic wounds, bedsores Carbuncles, boils, ulcers, burns with continuous oozing of blood and/or pus (including post-tumor surgical wounds)
techniques: Needle obliquely 0.1 - 0.2 cun from bottom to top. For best results, bleed the points and squeeze out the dark blood.

name: Zhiwujin & Zhiqianjin (T 11.08)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.08 Zhiwujin & Zhiqianjin , is a two-point set on the dorsal aspect of the index finger, along the ulnar margin of the proximal phalangeal bone (line F). Divide the proximal phalanx into thirds, and locate these two points at 1/3 and 2/3 of the distance between the PIP and MCP joints.
primary_indications: Primary: Acute or chronic enteritis, abdominal pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Fish bone stuck in the throat
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.2 - 0.3 cun , adjacent to the edge of the bone towards the palm.

name: Zhixian (T 11.25)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.25 Zhixian , is a two-point set on the dorsal aspect of the thumb, evenly distributed along the radial margin of the proximal phalangeal bone (line H). Divide the proximal phalanx into thirds, and locate these two points at 1/3 and 2/3 the distance between the MCP and IP joints. According to Dr. Chuan-Min Wang, this is a five-point set located in the same area.
primary_indications: Primary: Drooling in children, post-stroke drooling
secondary_indications: Secondary: Stomach cold with pain, diarrhea from Spleen qi deficiency Atrophy of the optic nerve, conjunctivitis, keratitis, optic neuritis, cataracts, tearing upon exposure to wind Toothache Intestinal hernia
techniques: Needle perpendicular 0.2 - 0.3 cun along the bone towards the palm. This point can also be bled.

name: Zhongbai (T 22.06)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.06 Zhongbai , is located on the TH channel and overlaps with Zhongzhu (TH 3) , which is on the dorsal aspect of the hand between the ring and little fingers, 0.5 cun proximal to the MCP joints of these fingers.
