primary_indications: Primary: Pain: acute back sprain, bone spurs, sciatica, back pain, knee pain, upper back soreness and pain, swollen bones, vertebral pain, spondylitis, degenerative arthritis, leg pain, headache, arm pain, calf pain, ankle pain (any part of the ankle, especially lateral) and heel pain due to Kidney deficiency Kidney disease or Kidney deficiency causing back pain and soreness
secondary_indications: Secondary: Meniere's disease, vertigo, migraine, dizziness High blood pressure with or without frontal headache Acute or chronic nephritis, acute and chronic pyelonephritis, cystitis, water metabolism disorders, edema of the extremities Disorders of the ears, tinnitus, difficulty hearing, sudden deafness Fatigue, blurry vision, astigmatism, exhaustion
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected side.

name: Zhongguan (T 22.25)*
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 22.25* Zhongguan , is located on the PC channel, on the palmar aspect of the hand, 0.5 cun distal to Daling (PC 7) , which is in the middle of the transverse crease of the wrist.
primary_indications: Primary: Sciatica Heel spurs, plantar fasciitis Uterine disorders: dysmenorrhea, fibroids, pain
secondary_indications: Secondary: Hemiplegia Food poisoning
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.3 - 0.5 cun . Needle obliquely and distally up to 1.5 cun for disorders of the bone, including bone spurs.

name: Zhongjian (T 11.05)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.05 Zhongjian , is located on the palmar aspect of index finger, at the center of the proximal phalanx (line C).
primary_indications: Primary: Hernia Asthma, bronchitis, pneumonia in children
secondary_indications: Secondary: Palpitations, chest stuffiness Dizziness, blurry vision, soreness and pain of the eyes Knee pain
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.25 cun . For HT, LU, and head conditions, needle 0.1 - 0.2 cun deep. For hernia and knee pain, 0.25 cun deep. Bleeding is also effective for hernia if there are nearby veins or dark spots. Needle contralateral to the affected side.

name: Zhongjiuli (T 88.25)
location: This point overlaps with Fengshi (GB 31) , which is at the center of the median line of the lateral thigh.
primary_indications: Primary: Migraine, back pain, cervical spondylosis, numbness and pain of the arms, hands and fingers, hemiplegia, bone spur
secondary_indications: Secondary: Dizziness, tinnitus Xing bi (mobile painful obstruction), leg or knee pain, facial paralysis or pain, weakness of the nerves Severe itching
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun .

name: Zhongliu (T 99.17)*
location: This point is an area from where the helix ends to the bottom of the ear lobe. It is at the same location as the auricular Tumor Specific Area 1 in Li-Chun Huang's Auricular Medicine.
primary_indications: Primary: Malignant cancer, tumor, ulcers, boils, carbuncles, lymphatic mass, toxic nodule or toxic mass
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.2 cun . 4-6 needles can be used.

name: Zhongquan (T 88.21)
location: This point is on the GB channel, 4.5 cun proximal to the center of the knee joint along the midline of the lateral thigh. It is 2 cun proximal to Xiaquan (T 88.20) .
primary_indications: Primary: Facial paralysis, deviation of the eyes and mouth, facial twitch, facial tic, hemiplegia, thrombosis, post-stroke complications Tinnitus, difficulty hearing
secondary_indications: Secondary: Shoulder pain Dysmenorrhea Skin allergy
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun on the healthy side.

name: Zhouhuo (T 1010.23)
location: This point is 1.5 cun superior to theear apex, close to Shuaigu (GB 8) .
primary_indications: Primary: Rheumatic heart disease, palpitation
secondary_indications: Secondary: Low back pain, fatigue, weak limbs
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun obliquely in any direction. This point can also be bled.

name: Zhoujin (T 1010.24)
location: This point is on the GB channel, 1.5 cun superior and 1 cun posterior to the ear apex.
primary_indications: Primary: Sciatica, back pain Rheumatic disease
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun obliquely in any direction. This point can also be bled.

name: Zhoukun (T 1010.03)
location: This point is nearthe BL channel, 1.3 cun lateral and 1.5 cun posterior to Baihui (GV 20) on both left and right sides, close to Luoque (BL 8) . Baihui (GV 20) is 5 cun directly above the midpoint of the anterior hairline or in the midpoint of the line connecting the apexes of the two ears.
primary_indications: Primary: Hemiplegia Asthma, shortness of breath leading to low back pain Fatigue, weakness of limbs, sciatica, and upper back pain
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun obliquely forward, backward or to the side. This point can also be bled.

name: Zhoulun (T 1010.04)
location: This point is nearthe BL channel, 1.3 cun lateral and 1.5 cun anterior to Baihui (GV 20) on both left and right sides, close to Chengguang (BL 6) and Tongtian (BL 7) . Baihui (GV 20) is 5 cun directly above the midpoint of the anterior hairline or in the midpoint of the line connecting the apexes of the two ears.
primary_indications: Primary: Brain tumor Hemiplegia Shortness of breath, asthma, weakness of the limbs, fatigue
techniques: Needle 0.1 - 0.3 cun . Needle contralateral to the affected area. This point can also be bled.

name: Zhoushui (T 1010.25)
location: This is a two-point set on the Du (governing) channel with the first point on the tip of the external occipital protuberance and the second point 0.8 cun above the first.
primary_indications: Primary: Lower back spinal pain, lower limb paralysis, weakness and numbness of the lower extremities
techniques: Needle perpendicularly 0.1 - 0.3 cun or obliquely, touching the bone. Needling to touch the skull will stimulate the Kidney to help treat spinal pain. This point can also be bled.

name: Zhouyuan (T 1010.02)
location: This point is nearthe BL channel, 1.3 cun lateral to Baihui (GV 20) on both left and right sides. Baihui (GV 20) is 5 cun directly above the midpoint of the anterior hairline or in the midpoint of the line connecting the apexes of the two ears.
primary_indications: Primary: Hemiplegia Asthma, shortness of breath leading to low back pain Fatigue, weakness of limbs, sciatica, and upper back pain
techniques: Needle obliquely forward, backward or to the side 0.1 - 0.3 cun . This point can also be bled.

name: Zhuyuan  (T 11.32)
location: The Master Tung Acupuncture point, T 11.32* Zhuyuan , is a two-point set located on both the radial margin of the IP joint (Line A) and ulnar margin of the IP joint (Line E) of the thumb.
primary_indications: Primary: All visual disorders: cataracts, glaucoma, near sightedness, far sightedness, blurry vision, floaters, dry eyes, etc.

name: Zongshu (T 1010.07)
location: This point is on the GV channel, 0.8 cun above the posterior hairline. Some books state it overlaps with Fengfu (GV 16) , which is 1 cun above the midpoint of the posterior hairline, while others say it overlaps with Yamen (GV 15) , which is 0.5 cun above the midpoint of the posterior hairline.
primary_indications: Primary: Aphasia Neck pain Palpitations, weakness of the heart Cholera, summer time enteritis with vomiting and diarrhea
techniques: Needle 0.1-0.2 cun . This point should not be needled more than 0.2 cun deep unless treating aphasia, which the needling depth is 0.3 cun . This point works best when it is bled. Pinch the muscles first prior to bleeding.

name: Zuqianjin (T 77.24)
location: This point is between the ST and GB channels, 2 cun lateral and 7 cun distal to Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament below the knee when it is flexed.
primary_indications: Primary: Acute enteritis Laryngitis, tonsillitis Pain in the shoulder area, supraspinatus tendonitis
secondary_indications: Secondary: Throat abscesses, thyroiditis, fish bone stuck in the throat, mei he qi (plum-pit qi)
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun . This point can also be bled.

name: Zuwujin (T 77.25)
location: This point is between the ST and GB channels, 2 cun lateral and 9 cun distal to Dubi (ST 35) , which is in the depression lateral to the patella ligament below the knee when it is flexed.
primary_indications: Primary: Acute enteritis Laryngitis, tonsillitis Shoulder pain, supraspinatus tendonitis
secondary_indications: Secondary: Throat abscesses, thyroiditis, fish bone stuck in the throat, mei he qi (plum-pit qi)
techniques: Needle 1 - 2 cun . This point can also be bled.
